Notes: As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, from 11:59 pm on Thursday 3 June 2021, there were some modest easing of restrictions impacting residents of Greater Melbourne and a more significant easing of restrictions impacting regional Victoria.  These changes are in response to continued community transmission within Greater Melbourne and no community transmission within regional Victoria within the last week.   In metropolitan Melbourne schools and universities:   “TAFE and university study must be done from home.  Schools and face-to-face learning are open for  students enrolled in Years 11 and 12, and any other students enrolled in Unit 3/4 VCE studies or the final year of a VCAL qualification or IB qualification  vulnerable children  children of authorised workers who cannot work from home or who are working from home and cannot provide supervision.”    In regional Victoria:   “Schools can resume face-to-face learning for all year levels.  Universities and higher education facilities can resume face-to-face learning with a density quotient of 1 person per 4 sqm.”      Greater Melbourne has the most restrictive government policy response to COVID-19 (including policies specifically related to school/university closures).  In Greater Melbourne some school students (in additional to children of authorized workers and vulnerable children) are able to attend face to face schooling.  Therefore, code changed to a 2.        https://web.archive.org/web/20210604010742/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604011649/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-2

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website on the 9th June 2021 media release Victoria’s current restrictions were to be further eased from 11.59pm Thursday 10 June.    A statement from the Acting Premier of Victoria, also published on 9th June 2021, stated that “In good news for families, schools will be able to resume face-to-face learning for all students from Friday [11th June 2021].”  The Workplace Directions (No 32) also came into effect on 11:59:00am on 12 June 2021.  Schools and higher education are open for in person teaching/learning.  Nonetheless, these directions, in part impose a density requirement of one person per 4 square meters.  This applies, to the non-classroom/teaching spaces of child care services, schools, and higher education institutions.      “The density quotient does, however, still apply to office areas including shared spaces that form part of an office area, spaces such as lunchrooms, photocopier room, principal’s office, back of reception and resource rooms. The density quotient also applies to any publicly accessible areas (including in relation to a school, non-school senior secondary providers, or childcare or early childhood service, or higher education service), and any such publicly accessible areas that are subject to the signage requirements under subclause (20).”    Therefore, changed to a 1T code.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111828/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-3   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111735/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-9-june-2021   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617114259/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Workplace-Directions-%28No-32%29-10-June-2021.pdf

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website on the 9th June 2021 media release Victoria’s current restrictions were to be further eased from 11.59pm Thursday 10 June.    A statement from the Acting Premier of Victoria, also published on 9th June 2021, stated that “In good news for families, schools will be able to resume face-to-face learning for all students from Friday [11th June 2021].”  However, the Workplace Directions (No 32) also came into effect on 11:59:00am on 12 June 2021.   These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 10 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021.  Schools and higher education are open for in person teaching/learning.  Nonetheless, these directions, in part impose a density requirement of one person per 4 square meters.  This applies, to the non-classroom/teaching spaces of child care services, schools, and higher education institutions.      “The density quotient does, however, still apply to office areas including shared spaces that form part of an office area, spaces such as lunchrooms, photocopier room, principal’s office, back of reception and resource rooms. The density quotient also applies to any publicly accessible areas (including in relation to a school, non-school senior secondary providers, or childcare or early childhood service, or higher education service), and any such publicly accessible areas that are subject to the signage requirements under subclause (20).”    Therefore, maintain a 1T code.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111828/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-3   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111735/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-9-june-2021   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617114259/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Workplace-Directions-%28No-32%29-10-June-2021.pdf

Coded as a 2T in light of information found at the archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210618131254/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/210616%20-%20Table%20of%20Restrictions_2.pdf  States for both regional Victoria and Metropolitan Sydney: “Higher education and training: If you can study from home, you should continue to study from home”

Originally coded by Lucy Ellen 18 Jun 2021 13:11:36. Originally Coded at a 1T.  Original note below.   Recoded as a 2T in light of information found at the archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210618131254/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/210616%20-%20Table%20of%20Restrictions_2.pdf   States for both regional Victoria and Metropolitan Sydney: “Higher education and training: If you can study from home, you should continue to study from home”    Original Note:   “As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, and in response to reducing levels of community transmission of COVID-19, restriction for both Greater Melbourne and the rest/regional Victoria were, overall/in general, relaxed from 11:59pm on Thursday 17 June 2021.      For Victoria The Workplace Directions (No. 33) come into force at 11.59pm 17 June 2021 and replace the Workplace Directions (No. 32).  These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 24 June 2021.    These directions maintain the previous density requirement of one person per 4 square meters.  This applies, to the non-classroom/teaching spaces of child care services, schools, and higher education institutions.      “The density quotient does, however, still apply to office areas including shared spaces that form part of an office area, spaces such as lunchrooms, photocopier room, principal’s office, back of reception and resource rooms. The density quotient also applies to any publicly accessible areas (including in relation to a school, non-school senior secondary providers, or childcare or early childhood service, or higher education service), and any such publicly accessible areas that are subject to the signage requirements under subclause (20).”    Therefore, maintain a 1T code.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618130810/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2033%29%20-%2017%20June%202021.pdf”

A press release from the Acting Premier of VIC announced that “On the advice of the Chief Health Officer, restrictions in regional Victoria and metropolitan Melbourne will ease from 11.59pm Thursday 24 June.”  In Metropolitan Melbourne: “Schools: Open. Density quotient of 1 person per 4sqm applies, except in areas used by students Schools: Open. Density quotient of 1 person per 2sqm applies, except in areas used by students. Higher education and training: Study from home requirement removed. Density quotient of 1 person per 4sqm applies, except in areas used by students”  For Regional Victoria: “Schools: Open. Density quotient of 1 person per 2sqm applies, except  in areas used by students. Higher education and training: Study from home requirement removed. Density quotient of 1 person per 4sqm applies, except in areas used by students Higher education and training: Study from home requirement removed. Density quotient of 1 person per 2sqm applies, except in areas used by student”.   Therefore changed from a 2 to a 1 code.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210629005448/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus   http://web.archive.org/web/20210623015951/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/210623%20-%20Table%20of%20Restrictions.pdf   http://web.archive.org/web/20210629005720/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-5

New South Wales  In response to a growing cluster of community transmission within Sydney the Premier of NSW announced that more stringent policy settings would be in place for residents of NSW from Saturday 26th June 2021.  More specially for residents of Greater Sydney, including the Blue Mountains, Central Coast, Wollongong and Shellharbour (all in New South Wales):   Residents must only attend in person education if it is not possible to learn from home.    School holidays commenced in NSW on Saturday 26th June 2021, so this does not impact school attendance.  However, university and other tertiary education students are affected.  As an example the University of Sydney (see archived URL) has moved all in person exams and intensive courses online or otherwise rescheduled/cancelled.  However, the university library remains open for students to access with swipe access.    Decision made to code level 2 to indicate that the higher education sector in the Greater Sydney area is not able to undertake face to face learning.   Changed the code from Monday 28th June as this is the first day that the new government policy is likely to have impacted upon the operation of the higher education sector (ie. it is unlikely that classes were scheduled for over the weekend.)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210628140944/https://www.sydney.edu.au/study/coronavirus-infection-university-of-sydney-advice.html   http://web.archive.org/web/20210628124921/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/greater-sydney   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628115612/https://legislation.nsw.gov.au/file/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Temporary%20Movement%20and%20Gathering%20Restrictions%29%20Order%202021.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628115746/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx     The Northern Territory  The Northern Territory  According to a press release on the Northern Territory Government Covid-19 website, on the 27th June the Northern Territory “Security and Emergency Management Committee made the decision under the Northern Territory pandemic plan to lock down part of the NT community.  Effective from 1.00pm today – the Darwin, Palmerston and Darwin rural areas will enter a full lockdown for 48 hours.  That means the local government areas of the City of Darwin, the City of Palmerston, and Litchfield.  This follows confirmation of four new covid-19 positive cases all linked to the Tanami case.”  “Although it is school holidays, schools and vacation care will be closed except for the children of essential workers. Childcare centres will open only for the children of essential workers.”  Furthermore, leaving home to attend education is not one of the allowable reasons to leaving home under the current stay at home orders for the Darwin, Palmerston and Darwin rural areas.    “People are only permitted to leave home for the following five reasons. Masks must be worn at all times when leaving  home:  To receive health care or attend medical appointments. Including to get the COVID-19 vaccine  To undertake shopping and get necessary goods and services. Supermarkets will stay open, so there is no need to stock up on groceries.  To exercise for up to one hour a day within 5km of your home and only with members of your household or one other person.  To undertake essential work. If you can work from home – you must work from home.  In case of an emergency or if there is family violence or to provide essential care to a loved one or dependent.”  Decided to maintain the 2T code, indicating that the higher education sector is closed for in person teaching.  Reason for not coding a level 3 is that it is currently school holidays within the Northern Territory.  This is in line with the interpretation guide “If schools are closed, and this same closure policy then rolls into school holidays, we keep the code the same, for example ‘all levels of education remain closed’. This coding would only go down only once students actually return, when schools reopen”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210628121424/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/advice-care/covid-19-lockdown-restrictions-in-place  web.archive.org/web/20210627060745/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/updates/items/2021-06-27-covid-19-update-lockdown-restrictions-in-place   http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132726/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/business-and-work/essential-workers

New South Wales:  The government maintains that travel for work or education is allowed if it is not possible to do it at home.      In terms of children, it is the school holidays in NSW so this does not impact schooling. The government says:  ""Under the stay at home rules, accessing childcare is considered a reasonable excuse to leave your home.    Vacation care and childcare will continue in Greater Sydney and throughout NSW.    If your child is booked to attend a vacation camp or other activities during the holiday period, contact the operator for any changes to arrangements.""     see here:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210702185858/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/border-restrictions

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, from 11:59 pm on Thursday 3 June 2021, there were some modest easing of restrictions impacting residents of Greater Melbourne and a more significant easing of restrictions impacting regional Victoria.  These changes are in response to continued community transmission within Greater Melbourne and no community transmission within regional Victoria within the last week.   In Greater Melbourne employees:   “You must work from home, unless you are an authorised worker , or work for an authorised provider who cannot work from home. If you can work from home, you must work from home.  You can only travel to regional Victoria for work if you are an authorised worker, or work for an authorised provider, and your place of work is in regional Victoria. The restrictions that apply to you in metropolitan Melbourne follow you to regional Victoria. For example, you must wear a mask indoors and outdoors when in regional Victoria.  Authorised outdoor workers will be able to resume work and must maintain physical distancing of at least 1.5 meters from others..”  The vast majority of those on the ‘authorised providers and workers list’ would be considered essential workers and work places.  The updated list is slightly expanded compared to the list most recently previously released list.  Nonetheless, continued level 3 code.    However, it is noted that there are some work places/categories for services that are allow to continue which may not be considered essential.  For example, non-essential general retail is allowed to open for click and collect orders only and hospitality is allowed to remain open for take away orders only.  See link 3 for the list of current authorized workers and workplaces.      In regional Victoria:   “If you can work or study from home, you should continue to do so.  Workplaces like offices can increase to 50 per cent or 20 people, whichever is greater.  You can attend work in metropolitan Melbourne only if you are an authorized worker or work for an authorized provider.”      Greater Melbourne has the most restrictive government policy response to COVID-19 (including policies specifically related to workplace closures).  Therefore, continue 3 code.        https://web.archive.org/web/20210604010742/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604011649/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-2   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604013145/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/authorised-provider-and-authorised-worker-list

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website on the 9th June 2021 media release Victoria’s current restrictions were to be further eased from 11.59pm Thursday 10 June.    A statement from the Acting Premier of Victoria, also published on 9th June 2021, stated that “When it comes to work, there’ll no longer be a list [of approved workers/workplaces]– but if you can work from home, you should.”  However, the Restricted Activity Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne) (No 3) also came into effect on 11:59:00am on 12 June 2021.  These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 10 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021.  The direction requires the closing of a range of workplaces include:   “A person who owns, controls or operates a facility in subclause (2)(g) (arcade), subclause (2)(h) (amusement park), subclause (2)(i) (casino), (2)(k) (gaming machine area), subclause (2)(l) (brothel, sex on premises venue or sexually explicit entertainment venue), subclause (2)(m) (bingo centre), subclause (2)(n) (escape room), subclause (2)(p) (karaoke facility) and subclause (2)(q) (nightclub) must not operate the areas in those facilities that are accessible to the public during the restricted activity period.”    Furthermore, indoor operation of non-ticketed and seated events in the following venues is not allowed.  In practice, these venues/workplaces are therefore also closed:   “A person who owns, controls or operates a facility in subclause (2)(a) (theatre), (2)(b) (cinema except a drive-in cinema), (2)(c) (music hall, concert hall or auditorium), (2)(d) (gallery or museum except an outdoor gallery or museum), (2)(e) (State Library), (2)(f) (arena or stadium), (2)(o) (animal facility except an outdoor animal facility) or (2)(q) (convention centre)…”  Melbourne has the most restrictive COVID-19 restrictions on workplaces in Victoria and all of Australia.  However, in Melbourne, clearly non-essential workplaces are now open for in person trade.  This include: Café, restaurant, fast food store, cafeteria, canteen, winery, food court (indoor and outdoor spaces (according to the VIC government) COVID-19 webpage.     Therefore, changed to a 2T code.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617115913/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/current-restrictions-how-we-work-metropolitan-melbourne   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111828/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-3   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111735/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-9-june-2021   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617114259/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Workplace-Directions-%28No-32%29-10-June-2021.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617115928/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Restricted-Activity-Directions-%28Metropolitan-Melbourne%29-%28No-3%29-12-June-2021.pdf

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, and in response to reducing levels of community transmission of COVID-19, restriction for both Greater Melbourne and the rest/regional Victoria were, overall/in general, relaxed from 11:59pm on Thursday 17 June 2021.      For Victoria The Workplace Directions (No. 33) come into force at 11.59pm 17 June 2021 and replace the Workplace Directions (No. 32).  These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 24 June 2021.  Under these new directions no workplaces are required to close.  However, there are a range of restrictions on the operations of different workplaces.  For example:   Hospitality: “Open with COVIDSafe requirements: density quotient of one per two square metres. A hospitality venue can host up to 25 patrons before the density quotient apply. Electronic record keeping must be used.”   Retail: “Open with COVIDSafe requirements: density quotient of one per two square metres. Record keeping required where practical and electronic preferred.”  Full details available at links.   Therefore, change to a 1T code.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618131254/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/210616%20-%20Table%20of%20Restrictions_2.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618130810/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2033%29%20-%2017%20June%202021.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618131813/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-work

NSW South Wales  As published in a press release on the NSW Government COVID-19 website, a range of new restrictions were (re)introduced for some areas of NSW from 4pm on 23rd June 2021.  These tightening of restrictions was in response to updated health advice from the Chief Health Officer Dr Kerry Chant about the growing risk to the community.   For Greater Sydney, the Central Coast, Blue Mountains, Wollongong and Shellharbour; “The one person per four square metre rule will be re-introduced for all indoor and outdoor settings, including weddings and funerals.”  Maintained the 1T code.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210628123339/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/new-covid-19-restrictions-for-greater-sydney-23-june-2021

New South Wales  In response to a growing cluster of community transmission within Sydney the Premier of NSW announced that some workplaces would be ordered to close from Saturday 26th June 2021.  Workplace closures are in effect for Greater Sydney, including the Blue Mountains, Central Coast, Wollongong and Shellharbour (all in New South Wales).      The following places in Greater Sydney are directed to be closed to the public.  •	Pubs and registered clubs except for  o	selling food or beverages for people to consume off-site and  o	providing accommodation, including allowing food and drinks to be consumed in a person’s room.  •	Food and drink premises, except for  o	selling food or beverages for people to consume off-site  o	selling food to be consumed in a person’s room if in a hotel or motel  o	if the premises are part of a shopping centre, selling food or beverages for people to consume outside of the shopping centre  o	holding a wedding or funeral in accordance with relevant restrictions.  •	Entertainment facilities, such as theatres, cinemas, music halls, concert halls and dance halls.  •	Amusement centres, such as places to play billiards, pool, pinball machines or video games.  •	Micro-breweries or small distilleries holding a drink on-premises authorisation under the Liquor Act 2007 or cellar door premises, except for selling food or beverages for people to consume off the premises.  •	Indoor recreation facilities such as squash courts, indoor swimming pools, gyms, table tennis centres, health studios, bowling alleys and ice rinks.  •	Places of public worship, except for the purposes of conducting a wedding or funeral service.  •	Hairdressers, spas, nail salons, beauty salons, waxing salons, tanning salons, tattoo parlours, massage parlours.  •	Auction houses  •	Betting agencies and gaming lounges  •	Markets, except for food markets  •	Caravan parks and camping grounds, except for  o	permanent residents or other people who have no other place of permanent residence, and their visitors  o	people who were staying there on Friday 25 June 2021 and have not extended their booking.  •	Sex on premises services  •	Sex services premises  •	Strip clubs  •	Public swimming pools (except natural swimming pools, which may open)  •	National Trust properties and Historic Houses Trust of NSW properties (other than retail shops)  •	Nightclubs  •	Casinos, except for selling food or beverages for people to consume off-site and providing accommodation, including allowing food and drinks to be consumed in a person’s room..”  Given that in person retail has not been ordered to close, decision made to code as a level 2.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210628124921/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/greater-sydney   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628115612/https://legislation.nsw.gov.au/file/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Temporary%20Movement%20and%20Gathering%20Restrictions%29%20Order%202021.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628115746/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx

The Northern Territory  According to a press release on the Northern Territory Government Covid-19 website, on the 27th June the Northern Territory “Security and Emergency Management Committee made the decision under the Northern Territory pandemic plan to lock down part of the NT community.  Effective from 1.00pm today – the Darwin, Palmerston and Darwin rural areas will enter a full lockdown for 48 hours.  That means the local government areas of the City of Darwin, the City of Palmerston, and Litchfield.  This follows confirmation of four new covid-19 positive cases all linked to the Tanami case.”  “All businesses, retail outlets, hospitality venues, gyms, pools and community centres will be closed. Cafes and restaurants will be able to offer take-away and delivery services.”  Furthermore, it the NT COVID-19 government website clearly states that only essential workers are able to leave home in order to work.  See archived URL for list of essential workers.   Northern territory workplace closures are more restrictive compared to the New South Wales work place closures that came into effect on the 26th June 2021.  Therefore changed to a 3T code.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210628121424/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/advice-care/covid-19-lockdown-restrictions-in-place  web.archive.org/web/20210627060745/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/updates/items/2021-06-27-covid-19-update-lockdown-restrictions-in-place   http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132726/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/business-and-work/essential-workers

New South Wales:  Travel for work or education is a reasonable excuse to leave home if it is not possible to do it at home  ""Employers must allow an employee to work from home if it is reasonably practicable to do so. If you cannot work from home and you go to your workplace, you must wear a face mask (unless an exemption applies).""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210702185858/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/border-restrictions

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, from 11:59 pm on Thursday 3 June 2021, there were some modest easing of restrictions impacting residents of Greater Melbourne and a more significant easing of restrictions impacting regional Victoria.  These changes are in response to continued community transmission within Greater Melbourne and no community transmission within regional Victoria within the last week.     Within Greater Melbourne these extended restrictions are enforced by the Restricted Activity Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne) and the Stay at Home Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne).    These directions require all Entertainment and physical recreation venues to be closed (with exception that approved sporting events may go ahead but with no spectators) and also prohibit public gatherings.    Greater Melbourne has the most restrictive government policy response to COVID-19 (including policies specifically related to public events).  Therefore, continue 2 code.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210604015818/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Restricted%20Activity%20Directions%20%28Metropolitan%20Melbourne%29%20-%203%20June%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604010742/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604021312/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Stay%20at%20Home%20Directions%20%28Metropolitan%20Melbourne%29%20-%203%20June%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604011649/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-2   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604013145/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/authorised-provider-and-authorised-worker-list

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website on the 9th June 2021 media release Victoria’s current restrictions were to be further eased from 11.59pm Thursday 10 June.    The Stay Safe Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne) (No 2) also came into effect on 11:59:00am on 12 June 2021.  These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 10 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021.  These Directions allow for public out door gatherings of up to 10 people within Metropolitan Melbourne.     Outdoor fixed seated entertainment: Open up to 50% of seated capacity up to a maximum of 100 people per venue. Density quotient of 1 person per 4sqm applies.  This could include open large open air sports stadiums. As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, and in response to reducing levels of community transmission of COVID-19, restriction for both Greater Melbourne and the rest/regional Victoria were, overall/in general, relaxed from 11:59pm on Thursday 17 June 2021.      For Melbourne The Stay Safe Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne) (No. 3) came into force at 11.59pm 17 June 2021.These directions commenced at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 24 June 2021.   These restrictions allow for Public gatherings of up to 20 people.  For example, meeting outside in a park.   For Victoria The Workplace Directions (No. 33) come into force at 11.59pm 17 June 2021 and replace the Workplace Directions (No. 32).  These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 24 June 2021.  Under these new directions no workplaces are required to close.  However, there are a range of restrictions on the operations of different workplaces.    Clearly related to public events, For entertainment venues:  “Bars, karaoke facilities and nightclubs are open with seated service, a density requirement of 1 person per 4 sqm and no more than 50 people indoors.  Indoor seated venues such as cinemas can have 50% seated capacity and up to 75 people per venue and maximum group size of 10 people (excluding babies under 1 year). A density requirement of 1 person per 4 sqm applies to indoor non-seated areas.  Outdoor seated venues can have 50% seated capacity and up to 150 people per venue and maximum group size of 20 people (excluding babies under 1 year). A density requirement of 1 person per 4 sqm applies to outdoor non-seated areas.”  Therefore maintain 4T code.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618132230/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28Metropolitan%20Melbourne%29%20%28No%203%29%2017%20June%202021.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618131254/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/210616%20-%20Table%20of%20Restrictions_2.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618130810/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2033%29%20-%2017%20June%202021.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618133116/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings

As published in a press release on the NSW Government COVID-19 website, a range of new restrictions were (re)introduced for some areas of NSW from 4pm on 23rd June 2021.  These tightening of restrictions was in response to updated health advice from the Chief Health Officer Dr Kerry Chant about the growing risk to the community.   For Greater Sydney, the Central Coast, Blue Mountains, Wollongong and Shellharbour:  “The one person per four square metre rule will be re-introduced for all indoor and outdoor settings, including weddings and funerals;  Outdoor seated events will be limited to 50% seated capacity;”  http://web.archive.org/web/20210628123339/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/new-covid-19-restrictions-for-greater-sydney-23-june-2021

New South Wales  In response to a growing cluster of community transmission within Sydney the Premier of NSW announced that more stringent policy settings would be in place for residents of NSW from from Saturday 26th June 2021.  More specially for residents of Greater Sydney, including the Blue Mountains, Central Coast, Wollongong and Shellharbour (all in New South Wales):   With some limited exemptions any gatherings of more than 10 people regardless of whether the gathering is private or part of an organised event is not allowed.     Therefore coded as a level 2 – cancelling of public events required.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628124921/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/greater-sydney   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628115612/https://legislation.nsw.gov.au/file/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Temporary%20Movement%20and%20Gathering%20Restrictions%29%20Order%202021.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628115746/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, from 11:59 pm on Thursday 3 June 2021, there were some modest easing of restrictions impacting residents of Greater Melbourne and a more significant easing of restrictions impacting regional Victoria.  These changes are in response to continued community transmission within Greater Melbourne and no community transmission within regional Victoria within the last week.     Within Greater Melbourne these extended restrictions are enforced, in part, Stay at Home Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne).    The directions mean that for those living in Metropolitan Melbourne:   “There are only five reasons to leave your home  shopping for necessary goods and services  care and caregiving, including medical care or to get a COVID-19 test  exercise  authorised work and permitted study  to get a COVID-19 vaccination.  You cannot have visitors to your home or visit others except for care and compassionate reasons. Your intimate partner and single person bubble may also visit you.”  Regional Victoria no longer has a stay at home order in place.  Greater Melbourne has the most restrictive government policy response to COVID-19 (including with respect to stay at home orders). New South Wales  In response to a growing cluster of community transmission within Sydney the Premier of NSW announced stay at home orders which came into effect on Saturday 26th June 2021.  Residents of Greater Sydney, including the Blue Mountains, Central Coast, Wollongong and Shellharbour (all in New South Wales) were ordered to stay at home, unless they had one of the “reasonable excuses” to leave home.    According to the NSW government COVID-19 website the following are considered reasonable excuses to leave home:     “A reasonable excuse is if you need to  •	obtain food or other goods and services  o	for the personal needs of the household or for other household purposes (including pets)  o	for vulnerable people  o	if the food or goods and services are not available in the local government area that you live in  •	travel for work or education if it is not possible to do it at home  •	exercise and take outdoor recreation in Greater Sydney  •	go out for medical or caring reasons, including obtaining a COVID-19 vaccination  •	donate blood  •	access childcare  •	continue existing arrangements for access to, and contact between, parents and children  •	attend a wedding or funeral  •	provide care or assistance (including personal care) to a vulnerable person or to provide emergency assistance  •	access social services, employment services, services provided to victims (including as victims of crime), domestic violence services, and mental health services  •	move to a new place of residence, or between your different places of residence  •	undertake legal obligations  •	avoid injury or illness or to escape the risk of harm  •	in case of emergencies  •	for compassionate reasons, including where two people are in a relationship but do not necessarily live together  •	to provide pastoral care if you are a priest, minister of religion or member of a religious order.  Taking a holiday is not a reasonable excuse.”    This stay at home order is enforced by the Public Health (COVID-19 Temporary Movement and Gathering Restrictions) Order 2021 which came into effect from 26th June 2021.  Under the new Order, stay at home requirements have been extended to all LGAs in the Greater Sydney area which includes the Blue Mountains, Central Coast, Wollongong and Shellharbour. There are also additional restrictions across NSW. The Order has commenced and will be in place until midnight 9 July, unless extended or repealed earlier.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210628115210/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/greater-sydney   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628115612/https://legislation.nsw.gov.au/file/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Temporary%20Movement%20and%20Gathering%20Restrictions%29%20Order%202021.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628115746/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx

The Northern Territory  According to a press release on the Northern Territory Government Covid-19 website, on the 27th June the Northern Territory “Security and Emergency Management Committee made the decision under the Northern Territory pandemic plan to lock down part of the NT community.  Effective from 1.00pm today – the Darwin, Palmerston and Darwin rural areas will enter a full lockdown for 48 hours.  That means the local government areas of the City of Darwin, the City of Palmerston, and Litchfield.  This follows confirmation of four new covid-19 positive cases all linked to the Tanami case.”  …”From 1pm residents from Darwin, Palmerston and the rural areas must stay at home for the 48 hour lockdown period. People are only permitted to leave home for the following five reasons:  1.	Medical treatment, including COVID testing or vaccination  2.	For essential goods and services, like groceries and medications  3.	For work that is considered essential  4.	For one hour of outdoor exercise a day within 5 km from your home with one other person or people from your house  5.	To provide care and support to a family member or person who cannot support themselves.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628121424/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/advice-care/covid-19-lockdown-restrictions-in-place  web.archive.org/web/20210627060745/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/updates/items/2021-06-27-covid-19-update-lockdown-restrictions-in-place

New South Wales:   ""Stay at home orders apply to Greater Sydney including the Blue Mountains, Central Coast, Wollongong and Shellharbour until 11.59pm on Friday, 9 July 2021""    Queensland:  ""Parts of Greater Brisbane will remain in lockdown into the weekend, as authorities scramble to establish the source of two new Covid cases who moved extensively around the city and suburbs. The snap three-day lockdown had been scheduled to end at 6pm on Friday. It will be extended until 6pm Saturday in only the Brisbane and Moreton Bay local government areas after the state recorded three new community coronavirus cases.    Lockdowns will be lifted in the rest of the state – including the Noosa, Sunshine Coast, Ipswich, Logan, Redlands, Gold Coast, Scenic Rim, Lockyer Valley, Somerset and Townsville city local government areas, as well as Magnetic Island and Palm Island – but some restrictions, including a mask mandate, will remain in place.""    Western Australia:   lockdown will be lifted from midnight on Friday     Northern Territory:   Lockdown was lifted Friday afternoon     see here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702185858/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/border-restrictions    https://web.archive.org/web/20210702190201/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/jul/02/queensland-covid-update-three-new-cases-and-brisbane-lockdown-extended    /web/20210702190336/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/public-health-directions/what-you-can-and-cant-do

Most recent note relevant and up to date as of the 4th June 2021    Western Australia  The WA Government COVID-19 website states that “Based on the latest updated advice from the WA Chief Health Officer, Victoria has transitioned from ‘very low risk’ to ‘medium risk’ under WA’s controlled interstate border, effective from 10.00am, Thursday, 27 May 2021.  Travel from Victoria into WA will no longer be permitted, unless you are exempt.”  This is up to date as of the 4th June 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210531123423/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/wa-introduces-hard-border-victoria  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604102408/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-travel-wa     New South Wales:   The NSW Government declared the whole Victoria to be an area of concern from 4pm on 27th May 2021.  Travelers from Victoria must self quarantine for 14 days since last being in Victoria.   This remains up to date as of 4th June 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604102722/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/border-restrictions   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604103051/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Documents/interstate-concerns-notice.pdf       Australian Capital Territory  The ACT government COVID-19 government states that “All travellers:  If you leave Victoria after 11:59pm on Thursday 27 May 2021 and enter the ACT you must stay at home unless:  to undertake essential work or study if they cannot work from home or remotely  to shop for essentials like groceries, medicine and necessary supplies  to attend to medical or health care needs including compassionate requirements, and looking after the vulnerable  to get a COVID-19 vaccine if you are not isolation or quarantine and have a scheduled appointment  to exercise outdoors, limited to one hour per day  for essential animal welfare purposes (e.g. to feed pets or livestock that live elsewhere)  to attend usual childcare arrangements, where parents or guardians need to undertake essential work or study.  If you are aged 12 years and over you must wear a mask if leaving your premises for any of these essential purposes. Mask wearing is not required if you are undertaking vigorous exercise outdoors.  The stay-at-home requirement will be in place until at least 11.59pm on 10 June 2021.”  This remains up to date as of 4th June 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604103802/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/community/travel/victoria2   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604103911/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/news-articles/new-stay-at-home-requirement-in-act-if-travelling-from-victoria     Northern Territory  The Northern Territory Government COVID-19 website states that “Anyone travelling to the Northern Territory from a COVID-19 hotspot which currently includes Greater Melbourne and Bendigo Local Government Areas must undertake 14 days of mandatory, supervised quarantine at the Alice Springs or Howard Springs quarantine facilities from 12:01am on 27 May 2021.”  On the 2nd June 2021, the NT Government further announced that “In addition to Greater Melbourne and the Local Government Area of Bendigo, the Acting Chief Health Officer has declared the remainder of the state of Victoria to be a COVID-19 hotspot for the purposes of travel to the Northern Territory effective 12 noon on 3 June 2021.”  This remains up to date as of 4th June 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604104900/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/updates/items/2021-05-26-greater-melbourne-and-bendigo-declared-covid-19-hotspots   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604104557/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604105207/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/updates/items/2021-06-02-covid-19-update-state-of-victoria-declared-a-hotspot     Tasmania  The Tasmanian government COVID-19 website states “Victoria has been declared a high-risk area from 2pm Thursday 27 May by Tasmanian Public Health authorities.  The declaration was made in response to Victoria announcing a state-wide lockdown and additional cases of COVID-19 being detected in the community.  Anyone intending to travel to Tasmania after 2pm Thursday May 27, who has been in Victoria in the 14 days prior to their travel, will not be able to enter Tasmania unless approved as an Essential Traveller. Quarantine and other requirements are in place for Essential Travellers”  This remains up to date as of 4th June 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604105517/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604105937/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania/travel-alert       South Australia  The South Australian government COVID-19 website states that “If you have been in Regional Victoria (excluding Greater Melbourne and the City of Greater Bendigo) after 7.00 pm 26 May and entered South Australia before 7.45 pm 28 May 2021, you must:  get a COVID-19 test as soon as possible and quarantine until you receive a negative result.  get tested again on day 5 and day 13 after arrival. There is no requirement to quarantine after receiving a negative result in your first test, unless you have symptoms.  ”    Additionally, “From 7.45pm 28 May 2021, if you have been in Victoria in the past 14 days you are not permitted to enter South Australia.  Entry is permitted for returning residents, people relocating to South Australia, and people fleeing domestic violence, however, on arrival you must:  quarantine for 14 days  get a COVID-19 test as soon as possible  get tested on day 5 and day 13 of quarantine  wear a face mask (covering mouth and nose) at any time you come into contact with the public for 14 day quarantine period (i.e. when seeking testing).”    This remains up to date as of 4th June 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604110704/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/restrictions-and-responsibilities/travel-restrictions   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604111830/https://www.sahealth.sa.gov.au/wps/wcm/connect/public+content/sa+health+internet/conditions/infectious+diseases/covid-19/testing+and+tracing/contact+tracing     Queensland  The Queensland government COVID-19 website states that “If you are entering Queensland and have been in Victoria in the last 14 days  From 1am AEST Friday 28 May all of Victoria will be declared a COVID-19 hotspot.  If you have been in a COVID-19 hotspot in the last 14 days or since the start date identified for the hotspot (whichever is shorter) you will not be allowed to enter Queensland unless you are a Queensland resident, except for a limited range of people who can enter for essential purposes.  The Border Restrictions Direction outlines the restrictions that apply to anyone who has been to a COVID-19 hotspot.  If you are in Queensland and have been to Victoria in the last 14 days  Greater Melbourne lockdown requirements continue to apply from 11.59pm AEST Thursday 3 June 2021  If you arrived in Queensland after 1am AEST Thursday 27 May and before 12.59am AEST Friday 28 May and have been in Greater Melbourne in the last 14 days, you must:  continue to follow the stay at home requirements. The Places of Concern Direction outlines these requirements  get tested if you develop COVID-19 symptoms.  monitor the list of interstate exposure venues for 14 days after entering Queensland  If you arrived in Queensland before 1am AEST Thursday 27 May and had been to Greater Melbourne in the last 14 days, you do not need to follow the stay at home requirements. However, you should:  get tested if you develop COVID-19 symptoms.  monitor the list of interstate exposure venues for 14 days after entering Queensland”  This remains up to date as of 4th June 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604112413/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/hotspots-covid-19   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604112235/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/government-actions/border-closing     Victoria:   The acting Premier of Victoria, James Merlino, released a statement on the 27 May 2021 stating that “On the advice of our public health team, Victoria will move to circuit breaker restrictions from 11:59pm tonight. These settings will remain in place until 11:59pm on 3 June – but if we can end that sooner, we will.”  This tightening of restrictions is in response to growing community transmission of the B1.617.1 variant which escaped from Australia’s hotel quarantine system.   These new restrictions applied across the whole of the state of Victoria and were enforced, in part, by the and the Stay at Home Directions (Victoria).  These directions required, with some exceptions, that Victorian residents not travel more than 5kms from their homes.    From 11:59 pm on Thursday, 3 June 2021, the travel from home distance was extended for 10kms for those living in metropolitan Melbourne.  The permitted travel distance from home restriction was abolished for Regional Victoria.  However, residents of Regional Victoria can attend work in metropolitan Melbourne only if you are an authorised worker or work for an authorised provider.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604113455/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings     https://web.archive.org/web/20210528082124/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/covid-19-chief-health-officer-update   https://web.archive.org/web/20210528082326/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-1   https://web.archive.org/web/20210528082507/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202105/Restricted%20Activity%20Directions%20%28No%2017%29%20-%2027%20May%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210528085737/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202105/Stay%20at%20Home%20Directions%20%28Victoria%29%20-%2027%20May%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210528083855/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/210527%20-%207%20Day%20Circuit%20Breaker%20Restrictions.pdf”

On 3 June 2021, the Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison released a media statement announcing a new temporary COVID Disaster Payment.  Australians who have had their hours of work and income significantly affected due to state lockdowns will be eligible.    “The rapid support will be paid weekly to those workers who reside or work in a Commonwealth declared hotspot and are therefore unable to attend work and earn an income as a result of state imposed health restrictions, which last for greater than one week.  Eligible recipients will receive up to $500 per week for losing 20 hours or more of work, and $325 per week for losing under 20 hours. They must not have liquid assets of more than $10,000.  The payment will be made in respect of the second and any subsequent weeks of restrictions.”  This announcement appears to have been made in response to the extension of stay at home orders in Greater Melbourne.    Those eligible for this new payment will be able to apply for it from the 8th June 2021.  Therefore , while the announcement is noted here, a zero code remains to date.      The payment will complement existing payments including the Pandemic Leave Disaster Payment.  The Pandemic Leave Disaster Payment is only available to those who “can't earn an income because you must self-isolate or quarantine, or are caring for someone with COVID-19.” Ordinarily this payment is for a maximum 14 day period only.  It does not meet the threshold for a 1 code according to the interpretation guide.  As such, a zero code has been coded and continues.     Since the abolition of the JobKeeper program on 28 March, Australia has not had an income support policy in place. This kind of relief would generally be the purview of the federal government and no states have had income support policies of their own during the pandemic either.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521024323/https://www.ato.gov.au/general/jobkeeper-payment/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604082420/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/news/covid-19-disaster-payment-people-affected-restrictions   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604082327/https://www.pm.gov.au/media/temporary-australian-government-assistance-workers   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604082852/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/pandemic-leave-disaster-payment

On 3 June 2021, the Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison released a media statement announcing a new temporary COVID Disaster Payment.  Australians who have had their hours of work and income significantly affected due to state lockdowns will be eligible.    “The rapid support will be paid weekly to those workers who reside or work in a Commonwealth declared hotspot and are therefore unable to attend work and earn an income as a result of state imposed health restrictions, which last for greater than one week.  Eligible recipients will receive up to $500 per week for losing 20 hours or more of work, and $325 per week for losing under 20 hours. They must not have liquid assets of more than $10,000.  The payment will be made in respect of the second and any subsequent weeks of restrictions.”  This announcement appears to have been made in response to the extension of stay at home orders in Greater Melbourne.    Those eligible for this new payment will be able to apply for it from the 8th June 2021.    However, this payment is only available for residents of Greater Melbourne.  The interpretation guide states: “This indicator does not have a binary flag variable to reflect geographic variation in policies. Therefore, we generally record the level of policy that applies everywhere across the jurisdiction - the highest common value of policy nationwide or statewide. We do not report any policies of a higher value that are only available in limited areas.”  Therefore the code remains at 0.     The payment will complement existing payments including the Pandemic Leave Disaster Payment.  The Pandemic Leave Disaster Payment is only available to those who “can't earn an income because you must self-isolate or quarantine, or are caring for someone with COVID-19.” Ordinarily this payment is for a maximum 14 day period only.  It does not meet the threshold for a 1 code according to the interpretation guide.  As such, a zero code has been coded and continues.     Since the abolition of the JobKeeper program on 28 March, Australia has not had an income support policy in place. This kind of relief would generally be the purview of the federal government and no states have had income support policies of their own during the pandemic either.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521024323/https://www.ato.gov.au/general/jobkeeper-payment/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604082420/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/news/covid-19-disaster-payment-people-affected-restrictions   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604082327/https://www.pm.gov.au/media/temporary-australian-government-assistance-workers   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604082852/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/pandemic-leave-disaster-payment

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, from 11:59 pm on Thursday 3 June 2021, there were some modest easing of restrictions impacting residents of Greater Melbourne and a more significant easing of restrictions impacting regional Victoria.  These changes are in response to continued community transmission within Greater Melbourne and no community transmission within regional Victoria within the last week.     Within Greater Melbourne these extended restrictions are enforced, in part, Stay at Home Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne).    The directions mean that for those living in Metropolitan Melbourne:   “People aged 12 years or older must wear a fitted face mask when leaving home, unless they have a lawful reason not to. For example:  if you have a medical condition, including problems with your breathing, a serious condition of the face, a disability or a mental health condition.  if you are in the car alone or with someone from your household  if you are doing strenuous exercise such as running or jogging, but you must still carry one..”    There are some exemptions for safety reasons or if it is necessary not to wear a mask in order to carry out your authorised work role.  Furthermore, if you are alone in a confined space wearing a mask is not required.  For example: an essential worker working alone in a closed office would not need to wear a mask.       Within Regional Victoria extended restrictions are, in part, enforced by the Stay Safe Directions (Regional Victoria) (No 3)  For Regional Victoria:   “Face masks must be carried at all times and must be worn indoors. You do not need to wear a mask in your own home or if a lawful exception applies.  Face masks are required outdoors where physical distancing of 1.5m cannot be maintained, for example, at a busy open-air market.”    Greater Melbourne has the most restrictive government policy response to COVID-19 (including with respect to wearing face masks).  Therefore, continue 3 code.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210604023611/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28Regional%20Victoria%29%20%28No%203%29%20-%203%20June%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604010742/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604021312/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Stay%20at%20Home%20Directions%20%28Metropolitan%20Melbourne%29%20-%203%20June%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604011649/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-2

These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 10 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021.  These directions maintained the same mask wearing requirements Melbourne.  Mask must be worn indoors and outdoors at all times, unless an exemption applies.   There are some exemptions for safety reasons or if it is necessary not to wear a mask in order to carry out your authorised work role. As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website on the 9th June 2021 media release Victoria’s current restrictions were to be further eased from 11.59pm Thursday 10 June.    The Stay Safe Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne) (No 2) also came into effect on 11:59:00am on 12 June 2021.  These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 10 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021.  These directions maintained the same mask wearing requirements Melbourne.  Mask must be worn indoors and outdoors at all times, unless an exemption applies.   There are some exemptions for safety reasons or if it is necessary not to wear a mask in order to carry out your authorised work role.  Furthermore, if you are alone in a confined space wearing a mask is not required.  For example: an essential worker working alone in a closed office would not need to wear a mask.    Therefore, maintain 3 code.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111828/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-3   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111735/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-9-june-2021   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617121311/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Stay-Safe-Directions-%28Metropolitan-Melbourne%29-%28No-2%29-12-June-2021-%28signed%29.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210610152436/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/20210609%20Table%20of%20Restrictions.pdf

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, and in response to reducing levels of community transmission of COVID-19, restriction for both Greater Melbourne and the rest/regional Victoria were, overall/in general, relaxed from 11:59pm on Thursday 17 June 2021.    For Melbourne The Stay Safe Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne) (No. 3) came into force at 11.59pm 17 June 2021.These directions commenced at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 24 June 2021.   These restrictions represent an easing in mask wearing requirements for Greater Melbourne.   As stated on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website:   “Face masks must be carried at all times and must be worn indoors. You do not need to wear a mask in your own home or if a lawful exception applies. Face masks are recommended when outdoors when you cannot maintain 1.5 metres from others.”  Even through this change represents a loosening of mask wearing requirements.  Requirements still meet threshold for a 3T code.  Therefore maintain 3T code.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618131254/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/210616%20-%20Table%20of%20Restrictions_2.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618133116/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618132230/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28Metropolitan%20Melbourne%29%20%28No%203%29%2017%20June%202021.pdf

As published in a press release on the NSW Government COVID-19 website, a range of new restrictions were (re)introduced for some areas of NSW from 4pm on 23rd June 2021.  These tightening of restrictions was in response to updated health advice from the Chief Health Officer Dr Kerry Chant about the growing risk to the community.   For Greater Sydney, the Central Coast, Blue Mountains, Wollongong and Shellharbour; masks became compulsory in all indoor non-residential settings, including workplaces, and at organised outdoor events  http://web.archive.org/web/20210628123339/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/new-covid-19-restrictions-for-greater-sydney-23-june-2021   http://web.archive.org/web/20210628124921/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/greater-sydney

NSW:   Must wear a mask when using public transport, hire vehicles, taxis and rideshare services, waiting for public transport at a bus or light rail stop, train station or ferry wharf. Masks are also mandatory when in an indoor area of a non-residential premises in NSW.     Queensland:  Masks are mandatory at all times when outside your home, unless:  ""you are alone in your car or with the members of your household  you are eating or drinking  you are at your usual workplace and can physically distance from others (except if you work in a hospitality venue or are a passenger transport operator)  you are alone outdoors or with members of your household  it is unsafe.""    See here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702192353/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/face-mask-rules  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702192624/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/protect-yourself-others/face-masks

While there have been some regional accelerations of the vaccine roll-out, Nationwide Australia is current at Phase 2a of the Vaccine rollout.  This means that :People aged 50 years and over; Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aged 16-49 years; Other critical and high risk workers are all eligible for vaccination.  As well as those who were previously eligible at earlier stages of the roll out.     Full details for current phased National vaccine roll-out plan can be seen at the first archived URL.   Australia is currently using the AstraZeneca and pfizer vaccines.  There is not individual cost of receiving a COVID-19 vaccination.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604085743/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604090219/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19

On the 4th June 2021 Australian Prime Minister announces that “the National Cabinet agreed to opening access to a COVID-19 vaccine to the following groups by 8 June 2021:  people aged 40-49 years not otherwise eligible;  all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aged 16 to 49 years;  NDIS participants aged 16 years and over and carers aged 16 years and over of NDIS participants of any age; and  temporary visa holders aged under 50 years who are currently in Australia and have been approved for return travel to Australia through the travel exemption process.”  While different states and territories are rolling out the vaccine at differing speed, from the 8th of June 2021, the general community of people 39 years and younger are not yet eligible for a COVID-19 Vaccine in every jurisdiction across Australia.   Australia currently has access to the AstraZeneca and the Pfizer Vaccines.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618124202/https://www.pm.gov.au/media/national-cabinet-statement-040621   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618124455/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine
https://web.archive.org/web/20210618125531/https://www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-greg-hunt-mp/media/press-conference-in-canberra-on-17-june-2021-about-updated-atagi-covid-19-advice

The remains up to date as of the 18th June 2021.   On the 4th June 2021 Australian Prime Minister announces that “the National Cabinet agreed to opening access to a COVID-19 vaccine to the following groups by 8 June 2021:  people aged 40-49 years not otherwise eligible;  all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aged 16 to 49 years;  NDIS participants aged 16 years and over and carers aged 16 years and over of NDIS participants of any age; and  temporary visa holders aged under 50 years who are currently in Australia and have been approved for return travel to Australia through the travel exemption process.”  While different states and territories are rolling out the vaccine at differing speed, from the 8th of June 2021, the general community of people 39 years and younger are not yet eligible for a COVID-19 Vaccine in every jurisdiction across Australia.   Australia currently has access to the AstraZeneca and the Pfizer Vaccines.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618124202/https://www.pm.gov.au/media/national-cabinet-statement-040621   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618124455/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine

The following people are now eligible for the COVID-19 vaccine:    All adults aged 40-49  All Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aged 16 to 49  NDIS participants, and carers of NDIS participants, aged 16 years and over  Temporary visa holders aged under 50 years who are currently in Australia and have been approved for return travel to Australia through the travel exemption process  Adults aged 18-39 can choose to receive the AstraZeneca vaccine.    This is in addition to the following people, who were already eligible for vaccination:  All adults aged 50 and over  Quarantine and border workers  Health care workers  Aged care and disability care residents and staff  People aged 16 and over with an underlying medical condition or significant disability  Critical and high risk workers aged 16 and over including defence, police, fire, emergency services and meat processing.  Individuals with an Australian Border Force outwards travel exemption in an eligible category    see here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210702192041/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine

As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, from 11:59 pm on Thursday 3 June 2021, there were some modest easing of restrictions impacting residents of Greater Melbourne and a more significant easing of restrictions impacting regional Victoria.  These changes are in response to continued community transmission within Greater Melbourne and no community transmission within regional Victoria within the last week.  However, a higher level of restrictions on visitors to residential aged care facilities remains in place across the whole state.    These restrictions are enforced by the Care Facilities Directions (No 31).   This direction prohibits any visitors to residential aged care facilities with exceptions for end of life care and limited additional provisions for residents with a mental illness.      Victoria has the most restrictive government policy response to COVID-19 (including with respect to protecting older adults).  Therefore, continue 3 code.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210604010742/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604024248/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Care%20Facilities%20Directions%20%28No%2031%29%20-%203%20June%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20210604011649/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-2

Per Directive 24/2020 under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204, which is still current as of 19 May (see https://archive.vn/QiCf8, ""mansuh"" = ""abolished"" in Malay; this specific directive does not have the ""mansuh"" tag), schools remain at level 4 since 17 August 2020 (see document, archived at https://www.dropbox.com/s/imjty2zg2ommsij/BRN-20200813-MOH-Directive24.pdf), which corresponds to ""full operation"" (see Ministry of Education school reopening plan, archived at https://www.dropbox.com/s/nivmvxxs7k3qo83/BRN-undated-MOE-SchoolReOpeningPlanProtocol.pdf).    However, some public health measures remain in place, including temperature checks.

No change.    Social distancing and other public measures in restaurants and cafes remain in place. Cinemas are only allowed to operate at 80% capacity.    ""1. Operators or operators of food premises are required to procure  Bruhealth QR codes specific to their premises and subsequently print  the QR code and affixed to the entrance area of ??the premises to be scanned  by the customer before entering and immediately before leaving the premises;  2. Food premises can operate at normal capacity rates;  3. Buffet food preparation is allowed on condition  food must be served by employees of restaurants, cafes or  food court;  4. Body temperature check must be done before entering the premises  food;  5. Owners of food premises must insure their employees  who handles and prepares food for constant wear  nose and mouth cover (face mask);  6. Unhealthy food premise employees are advised not to attend  working;  7. Ensure physical and social distancing including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Food premises are not allowed to increase the seating capacity  dine-in from normal capacity;  7.2 Food premises to provide special spaces or queues for  takeaway service;  7.3 Food premises to provide hand sanitiser;  7.4 Food premises are required to comply with internal guidelines  cleaning and sanitation of the premises.  8. Any food premise operators found not  comply with the aforementioned conditions, may be subject to action  law under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. Entrepreneurs of food premises are requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time.""    ""1. Cinema owners or operators are required to obtain a QR code  Bruhealth specific to their premises and subsequently print a QR code  and affixed in the entrance area of ??the premises to be scanned by  visitors before entering and immediately before leaving the premises;  2. Limit the number of visitors allowed to enter at any one time to 80% of the total normal capacity of the space  sitting cinema concerned;  3. Body temperature check must be done before entering the cinema;  4. Cinema owners or operators must ensure employees  them to always wear a nose and mouth mask (face mask);  5. Unhealthy cinema employees are advised not to attend  working;  6. Ensuring that the film will be shown will delay the screening time  after the end of a film screening to allow the cinema  clean the seats and surroundings of the cinema (fully sanitize);  7. Ensure physical and social incarceration including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Ensure the physical incarceration of cinema visitors to a minimum  one (1) seat. Customers who come in on a regular basis  groups are allowed to sit nearby;  7.2 Cinemas to display notice of the maximum amount of incoming capacity  at a time in an appropriate place;  7.3 Cinemas are not allowed to increase the seating capacity of  normal capacity; and  7.4 Cinema to provide hand sanitiser;  8. Any cinema owner or operator found to be non-compliant  the conditions mentioned earlier, may be subject to legal action  under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. The owner or operator of the cinema is requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time.""    See the Ministry of Home Affairs' guidelines on restaurants and cinemas, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/ns5m33kvui5uyen/BRN-20201017-MOHA-GARISPANDUANRESTORANFasa4.pdf  AND on  https://www.dropbox.com/s/zbabj0iiywl9j5h/BRN-20201017-MOHA-GARISPANDUANCINEMAFasa3.pdf

Unhealthy cinema employees are advised not to attend  working;  6. Ensuring that the film will be shown will delay the screening time  after the end of a film screening to allow the cinema  clean the seats and surroundings of the cinema (fully sanitize);  7. Ensure physical and social incarceration including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Ensure the physical incarceration of cinema visitors to a minimum  one (1) seat. Customers who come in on a regular basis  groups are allowed to sit nearby;  7.2 Cinemas to display notice of the maximum amount of incoming capacity  at a time in an appropriate place;  7.3 Cinemas are not allowed to increase the seating capacity of  normal capacity; and  7.4 Cinema to provide hand sanitiser;  8. Any cinema owner or operator found to be non-compliant  the conditions mentioned earlier, may be subject to legal action  under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. The owner or operator of the cinema is requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time.""    See the Ministry of Home Affairs' guidelines on restaurants and cinemas, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/ns5m33kvui5uyen/BRN-20201017-MOHA-GARISPANDUANRESTORANFasa4.pdf  AND on  https://www.dropbox.com/s/zbabj0iiywl9j5h/BRN-20201017-MOHA-GARISPANDUANCINEMAFasa3.pdf

No change.    As mentioned in the entry on 09 Feb, the Ministry of Health reiterates its advisories given the then-impending Chinese New Year celebrations,  ""Those with large families are permitted to hold private events at banquet halls in hotels or restaurants provided that Mass Gathering guidelines are adhered to, including provision of hand sanitizers and conducting temperature checks at the premises. If the number of family members is huge, limit attendance to a maximum of 350 people.""    The government reissued calls for the public to be vigilant in light of the then-impending Hari Raya Aidilfitri celebrations on 20th April, 2021.    ""Hosts are advised to schedule private events at home appropriately so as to prevent overcrowding at any one time, taking into account the size of one's home;     Large families with limited home space and who wish to organise a private event are advised to hold the event at a hall and adhering to the current guideline, including following the current mass gathering limit and scanning BruHealth QR code when entering the hall;    Anyone who are unwell or having symptoms are not allowed to visit or be visited by their family members;     The practice of shaking hands and hugs during Eid are not recommended; it is sufficient to give a gesture of greeting by placing the hand over the chest, smiling, or nodding the head as a sign of respect and greeting. Avoid as much as possible any attempts to touch or make physical contact with others;     Ensure good and well maintained personal and environmental hygiene especially the hands;    Practice correct cough and sneeze etiquette at all times; and    Avoid from sharing food and drink utensils such as spoon, fork, plates and glasses.""      The current maximum mass gathering size allowed was increased to 1,000 people, on 8th March. (See https://archive.vn/VEyvh)    The Ministry also continues to encourage safe distancing and other measures, including the limitation of events that are held to 2 hours.    See Ministry of Health's reiteration for Chinese New Year, archived at https://archive.vn/c7CpW  See Ministry of Health's guidelines/reiteration for Hari Raya Aidilfitri, archived at https://archive.vn/rgpTk  See also https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, the Ministry of Health's guidelines on mass gatherings, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/l0qb3n0bg8n31oz/BRN-20200924-Guidelines_MassGathering.pdf

No change in policy.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 09 Jun, public transport is operating.    The Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications' previous guidelines from September 2020 remains in force:    ""Public Transport Operators are allowed to operate 100% vehicle seating capacity. However, Public Transport Operators as well passengers are still required to adhere to the prescribed guidelines  by the Ministry of Health.  1. Scan the Bruhealth QR code before entering Public transportation. Only Green and Yellow Codes are allowed to use Public Transport;  ii. Use of face mask when  in Public Transport vehicles and along the way;  iii. Avoid physical contact.  iv. Avoid chatting while inside vehicle.  v. Check body temperature before boarding vehicle.  vi. For bus passengers, must sit along the way.""      See Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications' Guidelines (in Malay), last updated 07 Sep 2020, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/xj97s2roah5u1la/BRN-20200907-PengemaskinianGarispanduan.pdf  See US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/jtjOg
