No change. As previously noted, Reciprocal Green Lane with Singapore is suspended.    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 09 Jun, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Minister’s Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Minister’s Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for more information regarding Brunei’s pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  • Essential business travel (including official travel)  • Students  • Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  • Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/jtjOg  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/oTX9M    There is now also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.ph/SaQjP    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers almost daily (although in most circumstances, daily). See https://archive.vn/zGVEh (10 Jun), https://archive.vn/MvAQX (09 Jun), https://archive.vn/b8Vgj (08 Jun) for example.    There were no missing updates.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 09 Jun,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/jtjOg  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

(Frontline workers [Sinopharm]; senior citizens aged 60 and above [Oxford-AstraZeneca, Sinopharm]; students studying abroad [Sinopharm])    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    There are no major updates.  As there still is no announcements as to whether the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine drive for the general public has been extended beyond its 29th May enddate, it can be assumed that it has concluded.    Separately, the Star (one of neighbouring Malaysia's English-speaking newspapers) reported that ""[t]he Brunei government has issued updates on the Exit-Travel Application Guidelines, requiring outbound travellers to obtain mandatory Covid-19 vaccinations starting from August 1, 2021"".    See previous:  The Ministry of Health's press release on COVID-19 VACCINE for students continuing their studies abroad (dated 30 May), archived at https://archive.vn/E8gRc  The Ministry of Health's press release on encouraging COVID-19 VACCINE For The Elderly 60 Years And Over (dated 01 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/SZA4z  The Star Online's report, entitled ""Brunei requires mandatory Covid-19 vaccinations for outbound travellers"", archived at https://archive.vn/Wavys

(Frontline workers [Sinopharm]; senior citizens aged 60 and above [Oxford-AstraZeneca, Sinopharm]; students studying abroad [Sinopharm])    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    On 14th June, the Ministry of Health announced that vaccinations of people included in the Phase 2 of Brunei's Vaccination Strategy (teachers; childcare center staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases) will commence on Monday, 21st June; and that people in this group can start booking their vaccination slots on the BruHealth app from Wednesday, 16th June.    Additionally, it was reported in the Scoop that:  ""Since Brunei started its vaccine rollout on April 3, a total of 50,846 people or 11.2 percent of the population have received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine.  A total of 11,497 people, or 2.5 percent of residents, have been fully vaccinated.  The vaccine uptake among the elderly has been relatively slow since the rollout expanded to senior citizens on April 24, with just 17 percent of the targeted 38,000 seniors receiving their first dose.  Brunei currently uses Oxford-AstraZeneca and Sinopharm vaccines as part of its national vaccination campaign, with Moderna expected by the end of June, and Pfizer later in the year.""      See:  The Ministry of Health's press release ""Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase"" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled ""Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21"" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm

(Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    On 14th June, the Ministry of Health announced that vaccinations of people included in the Phase 2 of Brunei's Vaccination Strategy (teachers; childcare center staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases) will commence on Monday, 21st June; and that people in this group can start booking their vaccination slots on the BruHealth app from Wednesday, 16th June.    On 20th June, the Ministry of Health announced that the Moderna vaccine has arrived in Brunei.    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release ""Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase"" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Ministry of Health's press release ""COVID-19 Moderna vaccine arrived in Brunei Darussalam"" (dated 20 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/2onLe  The Scoop's report, entitled ""Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21"" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm

Vaccination groups: Phase 1 and 2 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare center staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (mRNA-1273)    On 14th June, the Ministry of Health announced that vaccinations of people included in the Phase 2 of Brunei's Vaccination Strategy (teachers; childcare center staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases) will commence on Monday, 21st June; and that people in this group can start booking their vaccination slots on the BruHealth app from Wednesday, 16th June.    On 20th June, the Ministry of Health announced that the Moderna vaccine has arrived in Brunei.    On 21st June, it was reported by the Borneo Bulletin that the Moderna vaccines are being utilised - ""scores of people lining up to receive their first shots were inoculated with the Moderna vaccine, which arrived in the country from Spain on Sunday""    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release ""Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase"" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled ""Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21"" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm    The Ministry of Health's press release ""COVID-19 Moderna vaccine arrived in Brunei Darussalam"" (dated 20 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/2onLe    Borneo Bulletin's report, entitled ""Second phase of COVID-19 vaccination begins"" (dated 22 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/XhM2i

Vaccination groups: Phase 1 and 2 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare centre staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran/mRNA-1273)    No significant updates. Elasomeran (the Moderna mRNA-1273 Covid-19 vaccine) was introduced in use in Brunei on 21 June, which was also the date for the start of Brunei's Phase 2 of its Vaccination Strategy.    On 28 June, the Star Online (syndicated from Borneo Bulletin) reported ""Some 76,471 people in Brunei had been inoculated under the National Covid-19 Vaccination Programme by June 26, with 63, 432 having received the first dose and 13, 039 their second dose"".    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release ""Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase"" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled ""Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21"" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm  The Ministry of Health's press release ""COVID-19 Moderna vaccine arrived in Brunei Darussalam"" (dated 20 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/2onLe  Borneo Bulletin's report, entitled ""Second phase of COVID-19 vaccination begins"" (dated 22 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/XhM2i  The Star Online's report, entitled ""Brunei: Over 76, 000 received Covid-19 vaccination as country goes 417 without local cases"" (dated 28 Jun), archived at https://archive.is/7F2bK

Mid-risk areas - except one - in Anhui provice were downgraded to low-risk in late-May, while new infections were found in Guangzhou, Shenzhen, and Foshan in Guangdong province; more than half of the new cases reported in 29 and 30 May are locally transmitted. Schools related to the cases are closed until further investigation is finished.    https://archive.vn/bfr64  https://archive.vn/szfTY  https://archive.vn/Tffj1
Schools in certain areas of Guangzhou and Foshan in Guangdong province remain closed due to the recent outbreak.    https://archive.vn/pSLdP  https://archive.vn/8AIT1
Wanquan town in Wenzhou went into lockdown from 11 June 2021 after an import case from Italy detested.    https://archive.vn/5l1xp

As by 21 June 2021, one area in Guangzhou (Guangdong) is high-risk and 12 areas in Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Foshan, Zhanjiang, and Dongguan, all cities of Guangdong, are mid-risk. Local lockdowns are in place in some of these areas.    https://archive.vn/KglsB
All high-risk areas were downgraded to mid-risk on 24 June; schools in these areas will remain closed until end of the month.    https://archive.vn/CCClU
Four areas in Foshan, Shenzhen, and Dongguan, all cities in Guangdong province, remain as mid-risk.    https://archive.vn/P30fr

The last mid-risk area in Foshan was downgraded to low-risk on 2 July 2021. The last three mid-risk areas in the mainland China are in Shenzhen and Dongguan.   https://archive.vn/kTq1C    No news suggests there are school closing in the mainland China, but students and school staffs living in those mid-risk areas have to stay home.  https://archive.vn/aq3rA
Seems no school is closed after three local cases were detected Ruili (Yunnan) on 4 July 2021.    https://archive.vn/30EjN

Seems no school is closed after three local cases were detected Ruili (Yunnan) on 4 July 2021.    https://archive.vn/30EjN

Mid-risk areas - except one - in Anhui provice were downgraded to low-risk in late-May, while new infections were found in Guangzhou, Shenzhen, and Foshan in Guangdong province; more than half of the new cases reported in 29 and 30 May are locally transmitted. One district is Guangzhou is put into lockdown on 29 May: 'Guangzhou government ordered residents on five streets in the city's Liwan district to remain at home and suspended non-essential activities, while entertainment venues and markets were closed.'    https://archive.vn/rNyux  https://archive.vn/5DE4O

Wanquan town in Wenzhou went into lockdown from 11 June 2021 after an import case from Italy detested. Residents can only leave home for medical reasons and if they work in supermarkets, farmer markets, and pharmacies.    https://archive.vn/5l1xp

As by 21 June 2021, one area in Guangzhou (Guangdong) is high-risk and 12 areas in Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Foshan, Zhanjiang, and Dongguan, all cities of Guangdong, are mid-risk. Local lockdowns are in place in some of these areas.    https://archive.vn/KglsB
All high-risk areas were downgraded to mid-risk on 24 June: residents in these areas are allowed to leave home for work and essential needs only.    https://archive.vn/5pHgr  https://archive.vn/lmlvc
Four areas in Foshan, Shenzhen, and Dongguan, all cities in Guangdong province, remain as mid-risk.    https://archive.vn/P30fr

All the mid-risk areas in Guangdong were downgraded to low-risk on 5 July 2021. As by 21 June 2021, one area in Guangzhou (Guangdong) is high-risk and 12 areas in Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Foshan, Zhanjiang, and Dongguan, all cities of Guangdong, are mid-risk. Local lockdowns are in place in some of these areas.    https://archive.vn/KglsB

'The airport in China's southern city of Shenzhen said on Saturday [19 June 2021] that anyone entering the premises must show a negative virus test taken within 48 hours before entry.  ... As the situation in Shenzhen became under control, from 20 June 2021 people can leave the city with a negative virus test taken within 48 hours before leaving.    https://archive.vn/OUMhj
Direct flights from Shenzhen to Beijing have been suspended until at least July 1 due to Shenzhen's local outbreak.    https://archive.vn/pST0F  https://archive.vn/zgQ6U

Transportation between Guangzhou and Foshan gradually resumes from 25 June with strict safety measures after all areas in Foshan became low-risk from that day and all high-risk areas in mainland China were downgraded to mid-risk the day before.    https://archive.vn/YwvAt
Four areas in Foshan, Shenzhen, and Dongguan, all cities in Guangdong province, remain as mid-risk.    https://archive.vn/P30fr

The last mid-risk area in Foshan was downgraded to low-risk on 2 July 2021; from 3 July 2021, people leaving Foshan do not need to show negative nucleic acid test  results obtained in the last 48hr. The last three mid-risk areas in the mainland China are in Shenzhen and Dongguan.     https://archive.vn/kTq1C  https://archive.vn/XACLO

'As of Saturday [19 June], 1,010,489,000 doses had been given to people in China, according to the country’s National Health Commission (NHC). More than 100 million doses had been administered in the six days up to and including Saturday. It’s unclear how many people have been full inoculated as the government does not release those numbers. But Zhong Nanshan, one of China’s top health experts attached to the NHC, said in March that the country is aiming to have 40% of the population fully vaccinated by the end of June.'  https://archive.vn/p83a4    The NHC expects to  have at least 70% of the population vaccinate by the end of the year.  https://archive.vn/mGzBx

The government continues to impose tighter measures on Viti Levu where COVID-19 transmission is occurring. An 18:00-04:00 curfew remains in effect islandwide. Returning individuals can enter Nadali but cannot leave again.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614182032/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/481511/fiji-authorities-tightening-restrictions-for-businesses-nationwide-as-of-may-21-due-to-covid-19-concerns-update-6

Officials continue to restrict travel between Viti Levu and other islands. The government allows residents from Vanua Levu and outlying islands to travel to Viti Levu for medical purposes or relocation with the Ministry of Transport's permission. Short-term travel between the islands remains banned. The Maritime Safety Authority of Fiji (MSAF) has suspended all nonessential outbound maritime passenger transport from Viti Levu. Inter-island cargo services continue; captains of vessels must register with MSAF and only offload cargo in designated areas. Cargo truck drivers may also continue to operate inter-island deliveries but must always remain in their vehicles while on Vanua Levu and outlying islands. After completing deliveries, drivers must return to a designated location to await return ferries.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210705205628/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/497706/fiji-authorities-continue-most-restrictions-amid-high-covid-19-activity-as-of-july-3-update-8

The government has offered a tax and tariff reductions, and loan repayment holidays (up to F$ 400 million of the total envelope) aim at protecting public health, supporting the economy and ensuring food security. A second fiscal package was announced as part of the FY2020-21 budget for the fiscal year beginning in August. The stimulus mainly consists of sizeable tax and tariff cuts. Fiscal and import excise duties on over 1,600 items were reduced or eliminated. Similarly, the budget includes cuts to the service turnover tax, environmental tax and departure tax.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614185644/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Fiji’s priority groups who will receive the COVID-19 vaccines first are:    Front-line workers (e.g airport workers, health front-liners, sea-ports, quarantine facility staff, hoteliers working in quarantine facilities, defense forces and some other essential workers) ;  The rest of the health workers across Fiji, including private practitioners, members of the disciplined forces, persons with existing medical conditions, and family members of front line workers;  Elderly/Older People 60 years and above; and  All individuals 18 years and above6. Why are these groups prioritized?Healthcare workers:  Health workers continue to serve on the front line of Fiji’s fight against this deadly pandemic. The occupation type, and job settings of healthcare workers place them at a higher risk of contracting COVID-19. Health care workers are also at a high risk of being exposed to COVID-19 as they provide critical care to those who are or might be infected.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614193411/https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Poppins&ver=5.7.2

COVID-19 nucleic acid testing arrangements for people arriving in Hong Kong from the Mainland, Macau, Taiwan and Singapore were adjusted from June 3.  'People aged over five who arrive in Hong Kong from June 3, and have only stayed in the Mainland or Macau on the day of arrival or during the 14 days before that day, should follow new testing arrangements.  For people who arrive at Hong Kong under the Return2HK Scheme and are exempted from compulsory quarantine, as well as those who are fully vaccinated and subject to a seven-day compulsory quarantine, the number of tests will be increased from two to three. Testing will be done on the third, fifth, and 12th day of arrival.  ....  Those who are not yet vaccinated and are subject to 14-day compulsory quarantine will have to undergo five tests on the third, seventh, 12th, 16th and 19th day of arrival.  Relevant exemption conditions will be amended by including the post-arrival test requirement as one of the exemption conditions.  ...'  https://archive.vn/mxVXe    Moreover, 'the Government announced today [3 June 2021] that two hotels will be added to the fourth cycle of the Designated Quarantine Hotel Scheme, bringing the number of quarantine hotels in that cycle to 33.  ...  About 9,000 rooms will be provided by the 33 hotels, with the contract period running from June 20 to August 31. Together with the blocked off rooms available at some hotels, the number of rooms that can be provided in the fourth cycle will exceed 11,000.  ...'  https://archive.ph/7DWJa
From noon 7 June, HK residents returning to HK from Guangzhou are required to hold a proof of negative nucleic acid test result obtained within 48 hours.    https://archive.vn/f00hO

The Government today announced that it will tighten boarding requirements for people arriving from Colombia and Korea from June 18.    It will move Colombia and Korea from Group C to the high-risk Group B specified places due to the persistent unstable epidemic situation in various overseas places and the prevalent transmission of cases involving mutant virus strains.    People who have stayed in any Group B specified places on the day of boarding for Hong Kong or during the 14 days before that day will have to present at boarding a negative result proof of a nucleic acid test for COVID-19 conducted within 72 hours before the aircraft’s scheduled departure, and the confirmation of a room reservation in a designated quarantine hotel in Hong Kong.     If they have been fully vaccinated, they will be subject to a 14-day compulsory quarantine at designated quarantine hotels, with three tests to be conducted during the period, followed by a seven-day self-monitoring period and compulsory testing on the 16th and 19th day of arrival at Hong Kong. Fully vaccinated means the suggested dosage of a recognised COVID-19 vaccine has been given in accordance with relevant guidelines at least 14 days before arrival in Hong Kong, the Government noted.     https://archive.ph/4gwGe

Indonesia arrivals face tighter rules    The Government announced that the boarding and quarantine requirements for people arriving from Indonesia will be tightened. The decision was made upon close monitoring of the epidemic developments in Indonesia, the prevalence of mutant virus strains and case importation risks that may be posed to Hong Kong.     All people who have stayed in Indonesia on the day of boarding for Hong Kong or during the 21 days before then will have to present at boarding proof of a negative result of a nucleic acid test for COVID-19 conducted within 72 hours before the aircraft's scheduled departure time. They must also present the confirmation of a room reservation in a designated quarantine hotel in Hong Kong. On arrival, they will be subject to the test-and-hold arrangement at the airport. On confirmation of negative test results, they must proceed to the designated quarantine hotels for 21-day compulsory quarantine via the designated transport arranged by the Government. They will undergo four tests during the compulsory quarantine period, to be followed by a seven-day self-monitoring period as well as compulsory testing on the 26th day of arrival at any community testing centre.    https://archive.ph/gC6wa

The duration of compulsory quarantine for inbound travelers who have stayed at medium to high-risk places will be shortened if they are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and test positive in a serology test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210706025721/https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2021/06/20210623/20210623_185151_832.html?type=category&name=covid19&tl=t

People arriving from the UK are subject to tighter quarantine requirements from June 28, including a 21-day compulsory quarantine at designated quarantine hotels.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210706025920/https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2021/06/20210624/20210624_212137_618.html?type=category&name=covid19&tl=t

IMF updated on 3 June 2021:  'Amid the economic recession during the pandemic, the government has announced and implemented fiscal stimulus of 12.2 percent of GDP, with the key measures including (i) heath-related spending to enhance anti-epidemic efforts (HK$28 billion), (ii) cash payout to eligible residents (HK$71 billion), (iii) employment support scheme (HK$91 billion), and (iv) other one-off relief measures through the Anti-epidemic Fund (HK$53 billion). In the FY2021/22 budget announcement, the government plans to provide additional countercyclical support of 3.7 percent of GDP. Key measures include: (i) providing one-off relief measures to households and enterprises (HK$38 billion), (ii) issuing digital consumption vouchers worth of HK$5,000 for each eligible resident in installments (HK$36 billion), and (iii) creating 30,000 temporary jobs (HK$6.6 billion).'    https://archive.vn/pFokx

In the FY2021/22 budget announcement, the government plans to provide additional countercyclical support of 3.7 percent of GDP. Chief Executive of Hong Kong, Carrie Lam, said in a conference on 1 June 2021, that the government will strategically combat the virus rather than imposing total lockdown. She also urged the public to get vaccinated as soon as possible in the next three ""crucial"" months.    https://archive.vn/b0BvL

'Centre for Health Protection Controller Dr Ronald Lam today [5 June 2021] said that boosting Hong Kong’s COVID-19 vaccination coverage can help bring normality back as soon as possible.  Dr Lam made the remarks at a press briefing this afternoon, noting that the current vaccination coverage in the city is still low.  “That’s the reason why we need to boost the vaccination uptake as soon as possible so that we can attain herd immunity to interrupt the transmission of the disease.  “We have been all along adopting the risk-based approach. If we can supplement it by an increasing vaccination coverage, we could revert to normal as soon as possible even though there are local cases here and now.”  He added that since the vaccination coverage is still low, people should keep wearing masks, cleaning their hands frequently and avoiding non-essential social gatherings.'    https://archive.vn/y5DyE

The Food & Health Bureau announced today that after reviewing the usage of the community testing centres and public demand for the testing service, the Government has decided to extend the operation period of 18 centres.    https://archive.ph/RS4lx

HK Government's Chief Information Officer announced on 7 June 2021 that the government has updated the tracing app, LeaveHomeSafe, which will enable users to store their vaccination and testing records.   'Under the vaccine bubble, there are more opportunities for citizens to present their COVID-19 vaccination records. The newly added Electronic Vaccination & Testing Record function in the LeaveHomeSafe mobile app’s version 2.0 allows users to scan and save the QR codes from their paper or electronic vaccination records for easy retrieval. The new function can also save electronic testing records.  Separately, iPhone users of the iAM Smart mobile app can save the QR codes of electronic vaccination records into Apple Wallet, the office added.'  https://archive.ph/mSquG    Meanwhile, the 'Food & Environmental Hygiene Department today announced that free COVID-19 testing services for targeted groups will continue and the online registration deadline has been extended to June 30.  To safeguard health, the department explained that aside from Sheung Shui Slaughterhouse practitioners who receive regular testing, the free testing services will continue for high-exposure groups such as staff and personnel working in markets, licensed hawkers and practitioners of cold stores.  People in high-exposure groups who have already registered and undergone testing may register again.  Testing agency Prenetics will be responsible for providing one-stop services covering specimen taking and testing.'  https://archive.ph/qKls6
The Government today announced that social distancing measures currently in place will be extended until June 23.    https://archive.ph/CkrAq    https://archive.ph/8ws8i#selection-629.0-633.51

'The Secretary for Food & Health today [3 June 2021] approved lowering the age limit for receiving the BioNTech vaccine to 12.  The Department of Health submitted the application for lowering the age limit to the Advisory Panel on COVID-19 Vaccines earlier, along with relevant clinical trial data for consideration.  After scrutinising relevant information, the advisory panel advised the health chief to approve the application.  Having regard to the panel's advice and taking into consideration the threat to public health posed by COVID-19, the bureau chief considered that the benefits of lowering the age limit for receiving the BioNTech vaccine outweigh the risks.  This can also protect adolescents from COVID-19 and enable them to resume normal school and daily life as soon as possible, the Government said.  It will announce the arrangements for providing the BioNTech vaccine to adolescents aged 12 to 15 early next week.'    https://archive.vn/yjV9d

'The Government will make it convenient for students to get vaccinated, Secretary for the Civil Service Patrick Nip said today [5 June 2021].  Mr Nip made the statement this morning. It comes after the age limit for receiving the BioNTech vaccine was lowered to 12.  He said: “We'll focus on two aspects. First is to disseminate information and the relevant data, messages to schools, including teachers, students and parents.  “I am glad that the medical community has already been doing this. It's important for us to tell the schools about the importance of getting vaccination, and also the safety, the efficacy of getting the jabs.  “The second aspect is that we would arrange very convenient and multiple channels to enable students, parents and teachers to get vaccinated.”  He called on people to get their first jab by the end of August.'    https://archive.ph/GXXi7

The government plans to keep schools open in prefectures placed under a COVID-19 state of emergency in an effort to avoid interrupting education, officials have said. Education ministry guidelines say that region-wide school closures due to the pandemic should be avoided from the viewpoint of ensuring healthy learning and for the mental and physical health of children.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210507102938/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/04/23/national/japan-emergency-schools/
No change in policy

For two weeks beginning June 7 to June 20, Okinawa Prefecture has temporary suspended prefectural schools, including high schools, special needs schools, elementary and middle schools.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607070236/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0603taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701184519/https://www.okinawatimes.co.jp/articles/-/764514  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701191112/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20210607_12/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701175835/https://www.city.okinawa.okinawa.jp/sp/userfiles/oki075/files/ClosureofSchoolsinOkinawaCity.pdf

On June 21, the temporary closure of prefectural schools in Okinawa has lifted. Schools are asked to resume complying with all infection prevention protocols and depending on infection rates in the locale, to stagger school attendance by groups.  In other prefectures, schools at all levels continue to remain open with cautionary measures including increased ventilations in classrooms, the wearing of masks in close quarters, and the establishment of a health management system for school doctors and pharmacists. There is currently no region-wide suspension on educational institutions and any temporary closure of schools are assessed on an individual basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621193410/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0617taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629231552/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0621english.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621010823/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629202136/https://www.kobe-np.co.jp/news/sougou/202106/0014458000.shtml  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629202245/https://www.tokyo-np.co.jp/article/113016
State of emergency extended further:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210601105602/https://www.timeout.com/tokyo/news/confirmed-japan-extends-covid-19-emergency-in-tokyo-until-june-20-052821

No change in policy. Measures in place until June 20: http://web.archive.org/web/20210606105156/https://www.timeout.com/tokyo/news/confirmed-japan-extends-covid-19-emergency-in-tokyo-until-june-20-052821
Still current, measures set to ease from Sunday June 20  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620215056/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/japan/coronavirus

The prefecture of Okinawa extends state of emergency to July 11: Karaoke parlors and bars not licensed as a restaurant must remain closed. Restaurants may continue to service customers provided restaurants follow shorten business hours from 5am to 8pm.    From June 21 to July 11, previous emergency measures for all other areas have transitioned to priority measures in the metropolitan and prefectures of Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hokkaido, and Fukuoka.  In the cities, local governments request all businesses operate between 5am to 8pm, with alcohol being served 11am to 7pm. Outside the cities, all businesses are requested to operate between 5am to 9pm, with alcohol being served between 11am to 8:30pm. Meeting halls, theatres, recreational facilities, places of tourism or leisure all must comply within these guidelines for shorten business hours.    Local governments continue to encourage all residents to stay home and to avoid going to crowded places or engaging in high risk activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210629224750/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629231552/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0621english.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629203611/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1014028/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629210148/https://www.city.osaka.lg.jp/seisakukikakushitsu/page/0000500056.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629210956/https://www.pref.kyoto.jp/kikikanri/news/corona_210618taiou.html

Some commercial facilities including movie theatres and department stores will be allowed to remain open but must close by 8pm. Moreover, a cap of 5,000 spectators or 50 percent of venue capacity will stay in effect for sports events and concerts. People are still asked to stay at home and refrain from nonessential outings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210601105602/https://www.timeout.com/tokyo/news/confirmed-japan-extends-covid-19-emergency-in-tokyo-until-june-20-052821

Still current - ""Some commercial facilities including movie theatres and department stores will be allowed to remain open but must close by 8pm. Moreover, a cap of 5,000 spectators or 50 percent of venue capacity will stay in effect for sports events and concerts. People are still asked to stay at home and refrain from nonessential outings."" Measures in place until June 20: http://web.archive.org/web/20210606105156/https://www.timeout.com/tokyo/news/confirmed-japan-extends-covid-19-emergency-in-tokyo-until-june-20-052821

In Okinawa Prefecture beginning June 7 until June 20, due to the ongoing state of emergency, all events regardless of size or location are to be postponed or cancelled: exemptions include events with no live audience, exams, or business recruitment activities. Until now, events with less than 1,000 people are to be held at facilities permitting 50% capacity, but after June 7, events are to be postponed or cancelled.  For events with 1,000 people or less, the notification period between June 3-6 will come into effect June 7. Tickets that have been sold by the end of the notification period do not need to be cancelled if the maximum number of people is 1,000 or less. After the notification period, new tickets are not permitted to be sold.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607070236/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0603taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701184519/https://www.okinawatimes.co.jp/articles/-/764514  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701194515/https://ryukyushimpo.jp/news/entry-1333234.html

From June 21 to July 11 in Okinawa, due to the ongoing state of emergency, all events regardless of size or location continue to be postponed or cancelled: exemptions include events with no live audience, exams, hiring activites, or Memorial Day services. Tickets for events that have been sold between the notification period of June 18-20 do not need to be cancelled if the maximum number of people is 1,000 or less. After the notification period, new tickets are not permitted to be sold.    In the rest of Japan, if the gathering does not require loud cheering, the event may proceed at 100% facility capacity for a maximum of 5000 people or less. For gatherings with loud cheering, the event may proceed at 50% facility capacity for a maximum of 2500 people or less. All events must end at 9pm.    Local governments continue to encourage residents to stay home and to avoid going to crowded places or engaging in high risk activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210629224750/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701183415/https://www.okinawatimes.co.jp/articles/-/771988  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621193410/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0617taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607070236/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0603taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629203611/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1014028/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629210956/https://www.pref.kyoto.jp/kikikanri/news/corona_210618taiou.html

Public transportation remains in operation.  As a result of the priority measures announced in Tokyo for June 21 to July 22, Tokyo Metro has announced new shortened hours for the commuter pass office, loss items office, and information desk until 8pm.  Regular services continues on Japan Rail with heightened prevention measures including increasde ventilation, physical distancing, disinfection, wearing of masks, and preventing passengers from rotating seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210629220538/https://www.tokyometro.jp/info/files/210618-teikikenuriba-soutori-ryokakuannaijo-eigyoujikanhenkou1.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629223100/https://www.westjr.co.jp/info/corona_taisaku.html

As reported by Nikkei Asia, on Friday May 28, the Japanese Government confirmed the extension of the state of emergency in nine prefectures until June 20. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga formalised the decision to keep the prefectures of Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka, Aichi, Hokkaido, Okayama, and Hiroshima under emergency measures for three more weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210601105602/https://www.timeout.com/tokyo/news/confirmed-japan-extends-covid-19-emergency-in-tokyo-until-june-20-052821

No change to previous policy. The Government of Japan continues to encourage residents to stay home and avoid areas or activities of high risk for infection.  ""When traveling across prefectures, take basic infection control measures, including avoiding the Three C's (closed spaces, crowded places, close-contact settings), and refrain from having dinner with a large number of people. If you have symptoms such as fever, please refrain from going home or traveling. Please refrain from unnecessary and unurgent movement to areas where the infection is spreading.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210629224750/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629203611/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1014028/index.html

Since January 2021, Japan has temporarily strengthened its border measures for arrivals after coronavirus variants were detected in the country. For now, only citizens and residents with valid documents can re-enter the country – the government has stopped issuing most types of visas, meaning tourists are effectively banned.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210601105920/https://www.timeout.com/tokyo/news/explained-japans-three-different-quarantine-rules-upon-re-entry-052821

No change in policy:   ""The re-entry into Japan of foreign nationals with status of residence who have stayed in these countries within 14 days prior to the application for landing will be denied, unless there are special exceptional circumstances.    Foreign nationals who wish to enter Japan for work or study but do not have existing resident status and who have visited the UK or this list of countries in the past 14 days are currently not permitted to enter until further notice, other than in exceptional circumstances. This guidance also applies to foreign nationals in possession of visas issued under the previous individual and Global Residence Tracks.    Other entry to Japan on a short-term basis, such as for business, tourism or to visit family, continues to be denied other than in exceptional circumstances. Business Tracks with all countries/regions have also been suspended until further notice. Japan has also introduced caps on the numbers of people able to arrive by plane, and bookings on some routes have therefore been suspended. Check with your airline.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210606105508/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/japan/entry-requirements
http://web.archive.org/web/20210620215253/https://www.japan.travel/en/coronavirus/

Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, and all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to the B.1.617 country/region designation provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210630005343/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210630010235/https://corona.go.jp/news/pdf/mizugiwataisaku_20210628.pdf
Support for life and employment, and emergency fund for people leaving work.    https://archive.ph/b6ILF#selection-2981.0-2981.53  https://archive.ph/qBzmV

No change to previous policy.  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210630020955/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210630022153/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

Ministry of Finance (MOF) decided to use safety net loan(loan limit:JPY720million) and  loan for crisis response(loan limit: JPY300million)  to support SMEs. Low interest rate loan provided by government financial institutions (JFC, Shoko Chukin Bank etc.). The government established private financial institution’s no-interest unsecured loan provided by utilizing prefectural directed credit programs. The loan limit is JPY30million. Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) established subsidy program for sustaining businesses. This program targets companies facing severe conditions in particular and provides them with subsidies for a wide variety of purposes that in general are considered effective in supporting them in sustaining or reviving their businesses. Eligible companies can obtain JPY 2 million (Maximum).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406144337/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/japan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html

No change to previous policy.  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210630020955/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210630022153/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701205040/https://corona.go.jp/action/

PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary.  In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, ""regional outpatient/examination center"" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.  On May 13, 2020, antigen test using nasopharyngeal swabs are covered by insurance and became available with positive tests requiring no follow-up PCR test. Antigen tests are used mainly when there are symptoms and prompt results are required--when clusters occur in hospitals and facilities, prompt results are requested from a large number of people with symptoms. Currently, in order to rule out false negatives, if tested negative with an antigen test, confirmatory PCR tests will be repeated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210701212007/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701212252/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701212926/https://omorimachi.com/pcr/timing/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701213151/https://www.aozoracl.com/coronavirus_pcr

Wide encompassing workplace closures continue for designated Dark Yellow Zones and some workplaces for Yellow Zones.  Certain areas in Phnom Penh have been designated as “Dark Yellow Zones” (effective through June 9). While there are no areas designated as “Red Zones” in Phnom Penh, individual buildings may be designated as subject to stricter lockdown measures. Non-designated areas permit in-person dining and are not subject to curfew measures, but prohibit gatherings of more than 15 people and prohibit certain “high-risk” businesses (such as schools, bars and other entertainment businesses, museums, resorts, massage parlors, cinemas, theaters, gyms, and sports centers), effective until June 16. Cambodian authorities have also announced lockdown measures and zone designations for and Sihanoukville (effective through June 4), Poipet (effective through June 5), and Kandal province subject to the aforementioned restrictions.    “Dark Yellow Zones” are subject to the following restrictions: All individuals within the lockdown areas must not leave their residence for the duration of the lockdown period, with some exceptions. Certain essential businesses may remain open despite the lockdown, but may be subject to stricter requirements, such as minimizing their staffing to no more than 2%.  “Yellow Zones” are subject to the following restrictions: All businesses are permitted to operate, except for schools and entertainment businesses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607172220/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All public event gatherings continue to be prohibited.  Certain areas in Phnom Penh have been designated as “Dark Yellow Zones” (effective through June 9). While there are no areas designated as “Red Zones” in Phnom Penh, individual buildings may be designated as subject to stricter lockdown measures. Non-designated areas permit in-person dining and are not subject to curfew measures, but prohibit gatherings of more than 15 people and prohibit certain “high-risk” businesses (such as schools, bars and other entertainment businesses, museums, resorts, massage parlors, cinemas, theaters, gyms, and sports centers), effective until June 16. Cambodian authorities have also announced lockdown measures and zone designations for and Sihanoukville (effective through June 4), Poipet (effective through June 5), and Kandal province subject to the aforementioned restrictions.    “Dark Yellow Zones” are subject to the following restrictions: All individuals within the lockdown areas must not leave their residence for the duration of the lockdown period, with some exceptions. All travelers must present a valid visa issued by a Cambodian Embassy or Consulate, possess a COVID-19 negative medical?certificate issued no more than 72 hours prior to the date of arrival,  and fully abide by locally enforced quarantine measures for 14 days at a hotel designated by the Government of Cambodia.  Travelers must also undergo a COVID-19 test upon arrival and wait in official facilities/designated hotels to receive laboratory results.? Health authorities will then oversee another COVID-19 test on the 13th day of quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607172220/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Cambodian authorities have also introduced the following requirements for prevention, containment, and response to the spread of COVID-19 for all travelers entering Cambodia by air, land, and water.? All arriving foreigners must:   Fully abide by locally enforced quarantine measures for 14 days at a hotel designated by the Government of Cambodia.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210611220233/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of March 12, 2021, under new Cambodian legal provisions, individuals who do not adhere to mandatory mask-wearing and social distancing may be subject to fines of $50 to $250.  Repeat offenders may be subject to a fine of up to $1,250. On March 23, the Cambodian government mandated the wearing of masks in geographic areas where there is an outbreak of COVID-19 in the community as determined by the Ministry of Health.  The mandatory mask-wearing and social distancing were earlier imposed on Phnom Penh and the provinces of Preah Sihanouk, Kandal, Prey Veng, Siem Reap, Svay Rieng and Banteay Meanchey. As of June 5, the Ministry of Health has made it mandatory for people in Kampong Speu, Takeo and Kampong Cham provinces to wear face masks at all times in public areas following an increase in new COVID-19 cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607172220/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607202354/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50852108/mandatory-face-mask-use-in-additional-three-provinces/

(Sinopharm, Sinovac, and AstraZeneca): As of 31 May 2021, a total of 2,625,338 and 1,988,224 target individuals received the first dose and second dose of the COVID-19 vaccine, respectively. The coverage among the total target population for the first dose is 26%, and for the second dose is 15.6%. The proportion of vaccine coverage in females for the first dose is 47% and for the second dose is 46%. From 1 May 2021 to 31 May 2021, a total of 927,339 individuals (female: 494,244,53%) received the first dose and 671,686 (female: 352,486, 52%) received the second dose through the mass vaccination campaign in Red Zone in Phnom Penh.  The vaccination programme in Cambodia has been carried out using a “blooming flower” strategy by administering vaccines from the core outbreak areas, where all adults in hotspots are heavily prioritized for vaccinations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607203854/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50864716/vaccination-masterplan-will-be-strictly-abided-to-says-pm-hun-sen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607201546/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/countries/cambodia/covid-19/covid-19-joint-who-moh-sitrep-48.pdf?sfvrsn=825e1c54_5&download=true

Previous note on 20th May suggested that reopening of schools would occur in June and may be staggered with some levels in some regions remaining closed till 7th June.  No further information has been found on reopening.  The code ""2T"" has been chosen to reflect the prior information suggesting that there may continue to be regional closures (Betio and Tarawa) of some levels until 7th June.

Previous note on 20th May suggested that all schools would be open by 7th June.  No further updates have been found and according to the Government website on Covid-19, the country is at Level 1 of its Covid response strategy ""Business as usual""    http://archive.today/2021.06.14-175510/https://covid19.gov.ki/docroot/

Restrictions were put in place in May following 2 confirmed cases of Covid aboard a fishing vessel.  The sailors were quarantined aboard a ship.  No further announcements have been found and the official Government Covid-19 page indicates that the country is at Level 1 state of preparedness which is described as ""Business as normal"".  It is therefore assumed that the restrictive measures have been lifted, although the precise dates are not known.    http://archive.today/2021.06.14-175510/https://covid19.gov.ki/docroot/

Starting July 1, some people who have been vaccinated against COVID-19 in countries other than Korea will be exempt from the 14-day self-quarantine requirement, meaning they can move around freely as soon as they enter the country. A similar exemption has been in place since May for those who were vaccinated in Korea.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620123746/http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20210616000780

No change on coming Exemption Plan.  The Ministry of Health and Welfare announced on June 24 that its quarantine exemption for those inoculated with Chinese COVID-19 vaccines will be implemented as scheduled, although the opposite public opinion is increasing.  https://archive.is/9L7st

Vaccinated travelers can skip otherwise mandatory quarantine from Thursday, July 1, 2021 if traveling for specific listed purposes.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210704180611/https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/health-environment/article/3139607/south-korea-offers-quarantine-free-travel-asias-zero

Laos has extended its lockdown Covid-19 prevention measures across the country for a further 15 days as the community spread of coronavirus in the capital continues.    Given the situation in neighboring countries and community spread in Lao capital Vientiane, the lockdown order would be extended until July 4, according to a notice issued by the Prime Minister's Office on Saturday.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210621172559/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/06/20/laos-extends-lockdown-measures-for-another-15-days

The Laos government has decided to extend the ongoing Covid-19 lockdown for another 15 days, effective from Monday (July 5) up to July 19 with certain relaxations.    Deputy Head of the Prime Minister's Office, Thipphakone Chanthavongsa, told a press conference in Lao capital Vientiane on Sunday that the situation in neighboring countries remained risky, and the Delta strain has been confirmed in Laos, therefore, the lockdown order will be extended until July 19.    The lockdown extension aimed to bring community transmissions of Cocid-19 under control, minimize the number of patients and ensure everyone in the society restore normal life under new normal conditions as soon as possible, said Thipphakone.    The current nationwide lockdown, imposed on June 19, was set to expire on July 4  http://web.archive.org/web/20210705164100/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/07/05/lockdown-extended-in-laos-to-curb-rising-covid-19-issues

The following entities are allowed to continue to operate: factories, banks and other financial institutions, the stock exchange, hospitals and medical centers, pharmacies, medical emergency services, postal service, telecommunication, electricity providers, water supply facilities, waste collectors, agricultural markets, convenience stores, supermarkets, gas stations, restaurants and coffee shops.  https://archive.vn/msqHc#selection-1959.0-1959.401

Laos has extended its lockdown Covid-19 prevention measures across the country for a further 15 days as the community spread of coronavirus in the capital continues.    Given the situation in neighboring countries and community spread in Lao capital Vientiane, the lockdown order would be extended until July 4, according to a notice issued by the Prime Minister's Office on Saturday.  Shopping malls, retail shops, supermarkets, minimarts, and fresh markets that comply with Covid-19 prevention measures may remain open.  Restaurants may continue to provide dine-in services in green zones, but must strictly comply with all Covid-19 prevention measures.  Outdoor exercise and non-contact sporting activities are permitted.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210621172559/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/06/20/laos-extends-lockdown-measures-for-another-15-days

Laos has extended its lockdown COVID-19 prevention measures across the country for a further 15 days as the community spread of COVID-19 in the capital continues.    Given the situation in neighboring countries and community spread in Lao capital Vientiane, the lockdown order would be extended until July 4, according to a notice issued by the Prime Minister's Office on Saturday.    The current nationwide lockdown, imposed on June 4, was set to expire on Saturday.    The notice outlines a gradual loosening of lockdown measures with certain strict measures to remain in place.    Shopping malls, retail shops, supermarkets, minimarts, and fresh markets that comply with COVID-19 prevention measures may remain open.    Outdoor exercise and non-contact sporting activities are permitted.    Restaurants may continue to provide dine-in services in green zones, but must strictly comply with all COVID-19 prevention measures.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210705164617/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-06/19/c_1310017088.htm

In order to be tested for COVID-19, you must qualify under the following testing criteria:  o   All new entrees to Laos;  o   People who have symptoms of COVID-19;  o   People with severe acute respiratory infection;  o   People who will travel abroad (and are approved by the Government of Laos COVID-19 Task Force)   https://archive.vn/msqHc#selection-2023.125-2041.98

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Laos? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to U.S. Centers for Disease Control’s (CDC) requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID-19 test,   U.S. citizens can obtain a COVID-19 test in Laos at The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE)  in Vientiane. The following information of U.S. citizens is needed to obtain a COVID-19 test: 1. Copy of Passport, 2. Itinerary, 3. A fee of 650,000 Lao kip (approximately $65) may be necessary for U.S. citizens. There are some exceptions to the cost of testing for diplomatic travelers.  A physical copy of test result will be available to pick up within 3 to 5 hours after collection of the sample (for urgent cases, results can be obtained within one hour)  The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE) is the central authority for COVID-19 in Laos (tel: 021-312351.) A, B, C:   The Ministry of Health is inviting members of the public for COVID-19 vaccination.  People in these groups will be given priority to get vaccines.  Healthcare workers Those at high risk of acquiring and transmitting infection including medical staff from the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Defense, Ministry of Public Security, laboratory staff, pharmacists, village health volunteers, health workers at private health facilities and medical students.  Older adults (=60 years old) People aged 60 years or above. The risk for severe illness and death from COVID-19 substantially increases with age, with older adults at highest risk.  People with underlying health conditions Those with underlying health conditions including lung or heart disease, diabetes, obesity, conditions that affect the immune system, and others.  Essential workers This group includes workers considered essential for maintaining the economy and providing services such as border control officers, security forces, teachers, civil servants, judges, transport, logistics, energy, mining, utilities, finance, communications, customs, and others.  Essential travelers Those currently in Lao PDR at risk of acquiring infection outside the home country and reintroducing infection upon return to home country. This group includes migrant workers, international students, business people, diplomats, international organizations, aid workers, and others.  https://archive.vn/PppkB  AstraZenac, Sinopharm, Pfizer   https://archive.vn/xW7J4

With effect from 00:00 on 5 June 2021, all individuals who have been to certain areas in Guangzhou (Guangdong, China) within the past 14 days prior to their entry to Macao must undergo medical observation for 14 days at designed venue.  https://archive.vn/DdCRR    Starting at 0:00 on June 5, 2021, those who have been to Brazil, India, Nepal, Pakistan or the Philippines within 28 days before entry, must present a certificate of three negative nucleic acid tests of covid-19, which are taken within 7 days and at least 24 hours apart each other, and a certificate of negative serum IgM antibody test or a certificate of vaccination, before boarding a direct or connecting flight to Macau. The relevant certificates must be issued by testing agencies recognized by the Chinese embassy in the local consulate, and the last negative nucleic acid test certificate must be made within 72 hours before boarding.  https://archive.vn/A8iQt

'In anticipation of an influx of returnees during the summer holiday, the government has enacted a one-stop arrival procedure for those who return to Macau via the airport.  From June 26, all arrivals at the airport, along with their belongings, are being transported directly to an unused zone at Pac On terminal to undergo a set of required procedures, which include ID checks and Covid-19 tests, before being admitted to the quarantine facilities.  The arrivals will be sent to quarantine hotels after receiving a negative test result. The one-stop system is intended to shorten the waiting time for the arrivals.'    https://archive.vn/3kMEp  https://archive.vn/wVkrt

IMF updated on 2 June 2021:  'Key fiscal measures in [Macao's] 2021 [budget] include (i) an early distribution of cash handouts through the Wealth Partaking Scheme in April to all residents amounting to 7.2 billion patacas, or 3.7 percent of 2020 GDP (with 10,000 patacas per permanent resident, and 6,000 patacas per non-permanent resident) (ii) electronic vouchers to all residents amounting to 5.9 billion patacas, or 3.0 percent of GDP to boost local consumption (each resident would be entitled to a start-up fund of MOP5,000 and a discount grant of MOP3,000) [opened to registration since May; see the previous notes for more information], (iii) support to local tourism amounting to 120 million patacas or 0.1 percent of GDP with eligible Macao residents receiving a subsidy of 280 patacas on local tours and 200 patacas on hotel accommodation, (iv) tax-relief and tax-exemption measures amounting to 1.1 billion patacas, or 0.5 percent of GDP (v) upgraded paid occupational training totaling 334 million patacas, or 0.2 percent of GDP (vi) free vaccines, amounting to 420 million patacas, or 0.2 percent of GDP. The 2021 budget provides for an extraordinary injection of 35.7 billion patacas, or 18.4 percent of GDP, from the Fiscal Reserve to counter the government budget deficit.'    https://archive.vn/pFokx

A nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M. that supersedes previous COVID-19 policies.  Recently, the curfew in Yangon was shortened to 10:00 P.M. to 4:00 A.M.   Residents of Yangon Region must abide by the following orders: 1.) stay at home unless going to/from work, 2.) employees of private organizations and businesses must telework (those working in banking and finance, gas stations, food and refrigeration services, production and manufacturing of pharmaceutical products, medical equipment production, and the distribution of drinking water and personal hygiene items are exempt), 3.) only one person per household allowed for grocery shopping, 3.) only two people per household allowed for medical treatment, 4.) a mask must be worn at all times when out of the home  http://web.archive.org/web/20210629031603/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Residents of Yangon Region must abide by the following orders: 1.) stay at home unless going to/from work, 2.) employees of private organizations and businesses must telework (those working in banking and finance, gas stations, food and refrigeration services, production and manufacturing of pharmaceutical products, medical equipment production, and the distribution of drinking water and personal hygiene items are exempt), 3.) only one person per household allowed for grocery shopping, 3.) only two people per household allowed for medical treatment, 4.) a mask must be worn at all times when out of the home,  The military regime has instituted a ban on gatherings of five or more people, and a nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M. that supersedes previous COVID-19 policies. Recently, the curfew in Yangon was shortened to 10:00 P.M. to 4:00 A.M.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210629031603/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Singapore Ministry of Health announced that beginning May 29, 2021, all passengers entering or transiting through Singapore from countries of high-risk for COVID-19, which includes Burma, must have a valid negative COVID-19 PCR test result taken within 72 hours of boarding. Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Burma?  If so, are test results reliably available with 72 hours? – YES     Testing is available at the following locations:  Air Cargo Terminal at Yangon International Airport: located on Pyay Road near the Than Pin Gone bus stop.  It is located near the DHL Myanmar warehouse at the airport, which is searchable in Google Maps.  Swab collections for PCR tests occur daily from 9:00 a.m. until 11:00 a.m. with results available the next day by 9:30 a.m.  The cost of the PCR test is 200,000 MMK.  Telephone numbers: 094 4409 9941 / 094 4409 9942 (*We have received reports that phone inquiries may not be answered, but the facility remains open).  N Health: located in Yangon at the Tourist Burma Building on the corner of Maha Bandula St. and Sule Paya St. (near Sule Pagoda).  Swab collections for PCR tests occur daily from 8:00 a.m. until 10:00 a.m. with PCR results available within 24 hours.  The cost of the PCR test is 200,000 MMK.  Telephone numbers: 01 230 3202 / 09 519 9122  Pun Hlaing Hospital: located in Yangon on Pun Hlaing Estate Avenue, Hlaing Tharyar Township, as well as at Pun Hlaing Clinic Downtown Yangon, No. 14/A, Taw Win Street (Corner of Ambassador St and Taw Win St), Dagon Township.  PCR and antigen tests are provided.  Please call or register online at least 24 hours in advance.  The cost of the antigen test is 45,000 MMK and the PCR test is 200,000 MMK.  Telephone number: 09 40 060 222  Samitivej International Clinic: located in Yangon at 9E/2 Kabar Aye Pagoda Road, Mayangone Township.  Requirements: copy of air ticket and copy of passport.  Swab collections occur daily from 7:30 a.m. until 10:30 a.m. with results available within 30 hours (via email with hard copy also available for pickup).  Please call first before visiting the clinic.  The cost is 420,000 MMK (includes doctor consultation, Fit to Fly certificate, sample collection fees, lab test) or at-home sample collection is available (includes doctor consultation, Fit to Fly certificate, sample collection fees, transportation fees, lab test).  Please contact the clinic for at-home pricing.  Antigen tests are also available.  Please contact the clinic for details.  Telephone numbers: 01 656 732 / 01 660 545 / 09 42427 4301  International SOS Clinic: located in Yangon at Inya Lake Hotel, 37 Kaba Aye Pagoda Road.  Swab collections for PCR tests are by appointment only.  Please call the clinic for more information.  International SOS will set up a tele-consultation with a doctor three days before your flight, with swab collection two days before your flight, and results available the day before your flight.  The cost of the tele-consultation is $63 USD, the PCR swab collection is $55 USD, and the cost for processing of the PCR test result is $143 USD.  Telephone numbers: 01 657 922 / 09 420 114 536  http://web.archive.org/web/20210629031603/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Swab collections for PCR tests occur daily from 8:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. with results available the next day.  The cost of the PCR test is 200,000 MMK.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210701170731/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Ulaanbaatar capital city administration will allow certain non-grocery shopping centers, stores, and markets to reopen provided they comply with health and safety protocols.  Malls, shopping centers, furniture stores, and home improvement stores reopened on May 8, and on May 10, automotive parts and other specialty stores can reopen. Generally, 80% of businesses will be allowed to operate normally. Businesses will be operating between 07:00-20:00.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607064913/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Starting from May 22, travel from city to provinces will reopen for fully vaccinated persons (after 14 days of their second does). Travelers no longer need entry permission from province authorities. If not vaccinated, travelers must present PCR testing. Children between the ages of 0-3 do not need to present test result.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607064913/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Starting from May 22, travel from city to provinces will reopen for fully vaccinated persons (after 14 days of their second dose). Travelers no longer need entry permission from province authorities. If not vaccinated, travelers must present PCR testing. Children between the ages of 0-17 do not need to present test result.  Travel into Ulaanbaatar is limited. If traveling from provinces with no infections registered, travelers may enter upon completion of a health?questionnaire. However, if traveling from infected areas, entry will be conditioned upon a negative COVID-19 test received within the past 72 hours.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614044101/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Mongolia has officially lifted the restriction on inbound/outbound travel starting from June 1, 2021. There are about 10 countries with open borders including the United States, and travels between Mongolia and these countries are allowed.  However, incoming foreigners must be fully vaccinated to before arriving in Mongolia. Unvaccinated travelers returning from foreign?locations are subject to a?seven-day?institutional?quarantine while fully vaccinated travelers are?subject to?a seven-day home?quarantine?upon arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607064913/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Mongolia has officially lifted the restriction on inbound/outbound travel starting from June 1, 2021. There are about 10 countries with open borders including the United States, and travels between Mongolia and these countries are allowed.  However, incoming foreigners must be fully vaccinated to before arriving in Mongolia.   Unvaccinated travelers or those who are within 14 days after vaccination returning from foreign?location are subject to a?seven-day?institutional?quarantine followed by a seven-day home quarantine while fully vaccinated travelers are?subject to?a seven-day home?quarantine?upon arrival.? Travelers subject to institutional quarantine will be placed into a government-controlled facility, usually a hotel at the traveler’s expense, upon arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614044101/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A limited number of flights are operating. Unvaccinated travelers or those who are within 14 days after vaccination returning from foreign location are subject to a seven-day institutional quarantine followed by a seven-day home quarantine while fully vaccinated travelers are subject to a seven-day home quarantine upon arrival. Travelers subject to institutional quarantine will be placed into a government-controlled facility, usually a hotel at the traveler’s expense, upon arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621100558/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The screening process is taking place for passengers coming from abroad. A limited number of flights are allowed into to Mongolia.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628030607/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

'Malaysia will extend a national lockdown beyond Monday to curb the spread of COVID-19, state news agency Bernama reported on Sunday [27 June 2021], citing Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin.  Lockdown measures were set to end on Monday. But Muhyiddin said they will not be eased until daily cases fell below 4,000, Bernama said.'    https://archive.vn/3DrRg  https://archive.vn/jSPan  https://archive.vn/chs1a

A 2-week national ""total lockdown"" came into effect on 1 June 2021. 'During the lockdown, which will run from June 1 to 14, only essential businesses will be allowed to operate and people have been told to stay within 10 kilometers of home.'  https://archive.vn/1ycRT    The 'essential businesses' include some manufacturing sectors:  'Large parts of Malaysia's manufacturing sector will be allowed to keep working, with reduced workforce capacity...   Among the manufacturing sectors allowed to operate with 60% of the workforce are those producing personal protective equipment including rubber gloves, electrical and electronics, oil and gas including petrochemicals, and chemical products, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said in a statement.  Other manufacturing sectors that can run are food and beverages, aerospace, packaging and printing, health and medical care, personal care and cleaning supplies, Defense Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob told a news briefing.'  https://archive.vn/MMTCd

Only travellers, who are permanent residents and citizens of Malaysia, and some exemptions are permitted to enter the country.    The UK: 'Entry to Malaysia for British nationals is prohibited. Some exemptions may apply, including: British nationals with permanent resident status, resident pass, My Second Home Programme (MM2H) pass, expatriates of all categories, including professional visit passes as well as dependants pass, spouse to Malaysian nationals (spouse visa) and students and temporary employment passes.'  https://archive.vn/hZakX    The US: 'Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? No, with very limited exceptions  Travelers must have formal written approval from the Malaysian Government before attempting to enter Malaysia. Malaysian Immigration operates a consolidated portal called My Travel Pass for most categories of pass holders to request permission to enter (or exit and re-enter) Malaysia.  Note that there is a different process for short term business travelers and student pass holders, please see below for more details.'  https://archive.vn/4t578

'Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced Monday [28 June 2021] a 150 billion ringgit ($36.2 billion) aid package to help people tide over the lockdown that has been extended indefinitely as the number of fresh COVID-19 cases shows no signs of abating.  In his televised address, Muhyiddin said the aid package includes 10 billion ringgit for cash handouts to middle-class and low-income households by the end of this year.'  In addition, the Malaysian government announced on 31 May 2021 a new stimulus package worth 40 billion Malaysian ringgit (roughly $9.68 billion) to help businesses and households cope with another round of “total lockdown” that started on 1 June 2021. (See the notes of 31 May 2021)    http://web.archive.org/web/20210628194627/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2021/06/f3c0461521f1-malaysia-extends-covid-19-lockdown-indefinitely.html
